Game is okay if you just want to experience the campaign in easy mode in solo or with a buddy, but the game gets stupidly challenging in higher difficulties. It's one of those games where you just get swarmed with hordes of zombies to the point where it fills your whole screen and you end up dying because you can't clear them fast enough, its just dumb. Game is unbalanced.

Basically It's fun to play it a few times but after a week of playing I suspect a lot of players will just quit and shelf this game until new content is added to try again for another week then quit again because game is too challenging. Most positive review for this game is probably from first impressions which i would agree its great but replayability is not there, i'd assume most players who left a positive review dont even play the game anymore.

The game is cool, very nice visuals and the campaign is well made...
... but it's too expensive, the DLC prices are unthinkable (at the least regional prices), and it's really hard to find match.
Most of the time you have to start a match solo and hope some more players show up. It usually takes 1-2 missions solo for someone to join.
There's a chance for trolls to join the game as well. They can prevent the mission from ending (can't kick when only 2 players in a match), and can team-kill when confronted.

Also, the game has a REALLY BAD leveling system, where you need exp AND in-game currency to lvl classes and weapons. To be able to play a class to it's full potential, you have to farm A LOT... I'm not even sure I would have anything to play when that time comes.

World War Z" is an exhilarating rollercoaster ride through a world overrun by zombies. From its gripping storyline to its breathtaking action sequences, this film keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The global scale of the zombie outbreak is depicted with stunning visuals and heart-pounding intensity. Brad Pitt delivers a compelling performance as a former UN investigator racing against time to save humanity. With its fast-paced plot, high stakes, and impressive special effects, "World War Z" is a must-watch for fans of the zombie genre and action-packed thrillers alike. 

Recommended to play 4/5

Very fun, has bugs and the game-play is slightly repetitive but extremely addicting. This is easily one of the best games to play for casual players, you can definitely play it competitively to due to the difficulty of missions solo.
  I am revising this part of my previous review to add more concrete clarity, the game has finite content which is its fatal flaw, but also its golden apple, what I mean by this is, once you complete every mission on hard mode, it gets very very VERY repetitive if you want to excel further, it is pointless to attempt beating insane/extreme with online matchmaking due to either lack of pc players or trolling/horrible console players, so to ale this, you need to play alone. 
           Playing alone however can be quite frustrating, you need to play a single mission countless times to gain enough knowledge to beat it or just be extremely lucky. This is where the casual aspect of the game dies and is no more. The game does a sharp pivot from casual to uber competitive due to the fact that the devs provide no alternative solo missions instead your forced to play missions designed for 4 people but as a solo person, which just further increases the difficulty. Not to mention the insane amount of grinding you need to do to level each class to 30, although prestige seems to be unnecessary which is nice.
     If you have no interest in this part of the game than unfortunately you have ran out of content, the same is with horde mode, their seems to be a hard cap on waves with randoms or solo that can effectively be completed, not to mention the copious amount of single session hours needed to progress in horde.

XL horde mode is absolutely amazing and would love more maps for them, the flexibility of play is much better with the hidden alcoves you can pay for!

Conclusion: Game is extremely fun but has a hard cap on content for most players, which is probably why the consistent player-base is copious amounts of new or returning players that play for short periods of time than quit, this in turn means the online community is the uber competitive snobs you will find in most comp games which is quite unfortunate. 
Highly recommend purchasing this though and giving it a shot, if you like it you REALLY  like it!

The game is far to reliant on having other players to make the missions reasonable to complete alone. 
This is the exact opposite of what a casual game wants, you need to be a competitive achievement hunter essentially if you want to beat missions alone, due to how tedious ,boring, boring, and frustrating it quickly becomes attempting to beat missions by yourself.

Now this wouldn't be a problem if the game had a plethora of players to fill lobbies... like at all.

Instead Saber continues to run the game like they have been and not innovating or trying anything new in the slightest. Oh we added some new boring component to the game that is basically the same thing as a previous item, but expanded upon very slightly.

Make difficulty more interesting, make a solo mode version of the missions, modify the zombies a little bit, etc so it's more accessible for casual players to enjoy. I know this is a lot to ask but possibly not make the ai useless, experiment with adding commands to the ai.

I  have this game on both PS5 and Steam.  I love it.  The episodes may be  repetitive, however they are never the same.  Between modifiers, other players and Zombie types, it never gets old.

It's just one of those games that makes a great first impression, but gets worse the more you play.

Pros:
-pretty well optimized, nice looking scenery
-hordes are pretty darn fun, especially at first.


Cons:
-Customization is abysmal, character skins look the same and gun skins are reused across multiple guns
-online is dead, meaning you are stuck with God awful AI
-I hate the gun system. You are forced to start with certain guns and have to get the others each time you play a round at random. Gun tiers are equally stupid.
-story chapters become very boring very quickly. Go here, shoot a couple meaningless zombies, fight a horde, kill a couple more meaningless zombies, fight a bigger horde, then watch an awful cutscene. Now follow that same script 30 more times.
-Gun sounds range from decent, to just plain awful.


I came off days gone so maybe my expectations were too high, but I don't think I can play anymore. It's just not fun

If you're the sort that wants their coffee and grits in single sentences, this game is Left for Dead 2 how it should've been done.  There I said it.

Oh, you're still here? Okay then, here we go! Any game can be nit picked down to minute details if you want, this game is no different. Do you really have to throw the switch on both generators nearly at the same time or the breaker will trip? Well if you have a couple portable gas generators hooked up to your home, this logic might be sound. But when you're talking about an industrial sized back up generator system for a hospital, or any industrial sized system for that matter, that's just not how these systems work. But it's an action game, big explosions, lots of bullets and blood and mass slaughter of zombies, who needs a bullet-proof plot? The John Wick theory is strong with this game and I love it.

I fully endorse the value in this game, too; whether you bought the base version for $30, Aftermath for a little more, or the Deluxe with the Arizona expansion for the full $60 (especially if you got anyone of those one sale). If you like zombie wave defense, slaughter types of games with just enough plot to make it interesting and slightly believable, that actually animates thousands of zombies onto your screen (and making them all hit-able targets) without lagging your computer to it's grave, this game is worth it.

Do yourself and your friends a favor, buy four copies and go kill some zombies ;)

[b]Now listen very carefully...[/b]

I spend MONTHS looking at this game page, watching reviews, analyzing whether or not this was worth buying... And after purchasing [b]Days Gone[/b], and immediately refunding it after 3 hours because the game felt like it was made by an indie studio, I then gave [b]World War Z Aftermath[/b] a chance with the refunded money...

[b]BEST DECISION! This is BY FAR the best "modern Left 4 Dead clone" game out there![/b]

Just make sure you get Aftermath too, since the 1st person mode is included in there. It's not "perfect" 1st person, seeing that you don't really "aim down sight"... But after a few minutes, you don't notice it anymore because you are too busy enjoying the game. :)

Zombies feel incredible, and are VERY satisfying to fight. And the Horde mechanic is SO good, and gives you a "bad a**" feeling while you fight them. Which is important, seeing this was the ONE doubt I had about the game, since I was afraid that the quantity of zombies in the horde mechanic, would decrease the quality of them. THIS IS NOT THE CASE.

The solo (offline) experience is decent, and I recommend giving it a go when you first buy the game, since you can enjoy the levels at your own pace. Also, if you join a public game with strangers, you mostly get pushed into a ongoing game, where they have already progressed the level quite a bit. Once you are happy with playing through the story, you can then increase the difficulty, and play with other strangers, for a more fun experience. :)

There is also a good progression system, and MANY characters to choose from, which all have a back story cinematic, that you unlock by completing a level with that character.

All in all, you will REALLY enjoy this, if you are looking for "the new Left 4 Dead" game. ;) Well worth the "non-sale" 40 euro price tag.

Killing zombies is very satisfying. I play this game online with randoms or with friends with bots. Horde mode is my favorite. The zombies react depending on how they are attacked. The physics is satisfying. 

Leveling up the different classes is very interesting and you can create different builds per game mode or situation. The Fixer and the Exterminator are ideal for Horde mode, but I think the Slasher is very fun too. 

I think this game scratches any itch depending on how you want to kill hordes or zombies.

I've been playing World War Z since launch on Epic store and still play it on Steam Today and just now I'm writting a review?

Anyways World War Z the game is based off the Movie which was not well received however i did like both the book and the movie but i viewed the movie as it's own thing. However i will say that this game makes the concept of the movie and makes it work. I will explain more of that later as i separate this review in sections.

Gameplay: The gameplay for Wwz is really good, you might think of this as just another horde shooter. However that is not the case. With the various classes and abilities you can use in combination with weapons and teammates. There's a lot of variety in what you can do. Zombies (Zeke) will climb over each other to form a pyramid to get you. The game has a lot of "defense" moments in which you prepare a defence and hold. However this game does them right and it doesn't feel repatative because sometimes you are met with an objective or the general environment is nice to play in. The classes and weapons in this game are all well balanced, no specific class or weapon is particuarly better then the other and it all comes down to playstyle preferense. For example i love playing Gunslinger with the sporting carbine. I have it maxed out to the point that my sporting carbine a tier 2 rifle is better then most of my tier 3 weapons. The overall flow of the game is great and the zombie types are really good from the Bull/Stalker and the annoying Screamer that tends to ruin your Nightmare runs because it screams, bringing in a horde. I only really played the PVP multiplayer once and got completely steamrolled so i don't have much of an opinion. But most people play it for the PVE anyways.

Story: The overall story of Wwz is broken up into Episodes and Chapters, each taking place in different locations with different survivors trying to achive a specific goal. I really love this concept because aside from Episode 1 New York in which your on your own until the last chapter where your working with the military. You get that feeling like your fighting a war against the undead. Episode 2 has you getting an orbital laser online to use against the Zeke. Episode 3 has you poisioning the streets of Moscow to clear it out so that one day you can take back the city and with Episode 4 you're evacuating Tokyo and later play as the same crew from Tokyo in Episode 7. But they mention that one day they will return. I do like how story wise the zombies are actively hunting to wipe out humanity and that the virus's soul purpose is to pretty much wipe out humanity. It feels like a genuine war in which they are being hunted rather then the zombies are just mindlessly wondering around looking for their next victim to eat. And in chapter 6 set in Rome you fight to take back the city and you do manage to take it back. And that concept is something i am very interesting in exploring more into. Civilization reclaiming their land from the zombies is definitely something i want them to explore more on. Adding more to that feeling of fighting a war against the undead.

Horde mode: I had to give this it's dedicated spot because to me i think I've spent more time on Horde mode then any other. It's the basic consept of defending your position and holding out. But you have a gate that you must protect. If destroyed, you lose. You are given resources that you can use to buy more weapons or defense setups. The hordes will get more and more difficult as each wave comes. You have 2 locations to defend and every 5 waves you will be relocated to the next spot. Note that you can never have both locations be under attack at the same time unless you happen to go over there and trigger a mini horde from making too much noise. But the horde mode is a great way to level up weapons and find good strategies in dealing with large hordes and using defense kits. I normally do like survival modes or horde modes. And sometimes they can get repetative but overall something with WwZ's horde mode just keeps me coming back no matter what. The idea of trying to go better then last time is what really keeps me going on this mode. And when you do break your own record, it's a feel good feeling. There's also Horde XL wich is Horde but with bigger waves in different locations which is a welcomed edition but can get more difficult.

Conclusion: World War Z is a great game, taking from the Movie which took nothing from the book. And made it great, the gameplay, maps, characters, story is all good and always has me and my friends coming back to play more of. I hope to see this game thrive and keep going. If you have been curious to picking this game up, It's worth it

The game is more annoying than fun. It's fun at times, but mostly annoying.
The progression is slow, any perks and upgrades cost currency, besides xp, that you have to grind trough completing the missions. To get most out of your weapons you have to grind challenges, to be able to buy perks for weapons. Completing a 3 daily challenge maps (which took much more time than necessary for a daily challenge) got me 10 points. The cheapest perk on shotgun costs more than 500. And actually useful one costs almost a thousand. Good luck grinding thoose.   
The game/map design leaves much to be desired. Like, you have to face zombie swarms at some point on a level, you have to prepare your defences, but at the same time you're already attacked by a timed swarm and bosses which sabotages your preparations. Sometimes zombies completely ignore you and your party and run in complex routes straight to the mission target you have to protect, and then you have only 30 seconds to defend it. This behavior is silly as well as the timer. Sometimes, playing with the AI you just don't have the firepower to deal with it fast enough.
Zombies who are about to attack you just sticks to your character. It doesn't matter if you run, climb or something like that, you'll get your damage.
The AI is absolutely useless and I wasn't been able to find anyone to complete a challenge map in 5 minutes, I'm not wasting more of my time on waiting.
Of course there's a "git good" aspect, I think you can cheese everything if you leveled up enough, but things becomes pretty boring, tedious and annoying pretty fast for me to get there.

[h2] Background [/h2]
[list]
	[*]I came from playing L4D2 with the expectation of having the same or better experience.
    [*]I have only played this with four of my friends. Never once in a public lobby.
    [*]All items I bought were during sales (Winter/Fall sales, etc.).
    [*]Very seldom played Horde Mode (and not once PVP). Cannot comment on that. All my reviews are on the 8 episodes thus far.
    [*]I have never played in third-person mode.
    [*]I don't care for weapon skins nor character skins. I just used the basic generic model.
[/list]
[h2] Pros [/h2]
[list]
    [*]Easy is too easy. Extreme is too hard (for my skill), thus for me, it's balanced.
    [*]Variety of weapons. Melee has a special class expert in that, the heavy weapon has a class for that.
    [*]Not a single Pay2Win except for cosmetic skins or weapon packs (that I don't really care about).
    [*]A massive amount of zombie spawn. Killing them feels very good.
    [*]The story and voice acting are on point for each scenario.
    [*]Stunning visuals (at least compared to the now very-dated L4D2).
[/list]
[h2] Cons [/h2]
[list]
    [*]You have to grind for money a lot. Played the Missile Command mission like, I don't know, 1000 times already to grind money.
    [*]Each Prestige level resets the whole skill class, wasting your money on buying the same skill again and again.
    [*]Limited maps; the eight episodes (25 levels) will feel repetitive, especially when you've completed all at least once, then repeat the process again with higher difficulties.
    [*]Cannot start the game at a checkpoint. If halfway through a chapter, and your entire team gets KO'ed, then you need to restart from the beginning, which is kind of frustratingly boring/repetitive.
    [*]No modding to add custom maps, or weapons.
    [*]Blue coins are VERY VERY VERY hard to grind.
    [*]Playing solo, AI is kind of dumb and won't do anything except following you, won't even pick up items (like medkits/equipment).
[/list]
[h2] What I would love if they add[/h2]
[list]
    [*]Button to quickly un-alive yourself if you're pinned, so you won't waste time waiting for the respawning countdown.
    [*]Separates zombie amount and zombie difficulties. Like it would be fun (for me) if there are a massive amount of zombies but only on just Normal/Hard difficulty.
    [*]Add an option to disable friendly fire (I know this is far-fetched; even L4D2 doesn't have this).
[/list]
[h2]Bugs I have noticed - at the time of writing[/h2]
[list]
    [*]On Missile Command mission, sometimes you can spawn out-of-bounds at the beginning and die immediately.
[/list]

I spent way, way more hours on Epic when they made it free during the pandemic, but decided to switch over out of spite and somewhat support the devs.

It's a good game when you just want to jump in with some friends and shoot some zombies. WWZ feels polished and all of the classes feel satisfying to use, often because they feel cohesive and have something unique to bring to the table. The ones I've enjoyed are Medic, Dronemaster, and Vanguard. There's a lot of content to enjoy, and it's easy to get back to once in a while.

The third-person perspective by design makes the game a lot more accessible. Plenty of my friends have nausea after playing an FPS game, but WWZ gives us the opportunity to have a nice time. That said, I still highly recommend you remove any camera shakes and motion blur, and to lower your mouse sensitivity.

L4D2 world-building, sound design, and overall atmosphere is a class of its own, but WWZ is immersive on its own right. The game is not perfect by any means, but I find it to be good enough as a successor to the former title.

I wish this game had first-class support for mods, but I'll take what I can get. The DLCs are good enough for me as only one person has to own it for it to be playable for the entire group. I like knowing there's probably a new episode coming out in a year or two for me to enjoy with friends, first-timers and old dogs alike.

I like the difficulty in this game, you can get killed rather quickly, tactics come in to play, and you can't just blast your way to a win.  Graphics are awesome, and the squishy sounds are delightful!

I'm actually surprised that WWZ has been supported by a developer for so long, I‚Äôve played it back in 2020 when I first bought the game on Epic and a lot of people hated it when it came out, saying it‚Äôs a ripoff of L4D,

But now it seems that people liking what Saber Interactive has done with WWZ‚Ä¶ and yeah I think they did an amazing job with the IP.

I was addicted back then when I started playing the game and until now I still play it occasionally, I got like 96 hours on my Epic account and I still enjoy it,

Well what do I think about the game??..... I'll say it‚Äôs worth it, now that I finally bought it on Steam, I can finally say that, yes WWZ is fun, enjoyable and addicting coop shooter to play, add points that there‚Äôs soooo many Zombies,

Also the game has been updated with bigger and better content, like just now (The Against All Odds Update, new Guns skins DLC and a reward to link your account on PROS and watch 4 hours of gaming live stream on twitch to earn an exclusive skins, ingame cash and points), the update is actually amazing and I love what they showed us, oh yeah did I mention that the update just came out of nowhere.

I mean c‚Äômon.... you can give some props to Saber Interactive that they haven‚Äôt given up with the game yet, they still support it in 2023 and gave the fans what they deserve. Saber Interactive is actually a good company now that I think about it.

I have so much mad respect to Saber Interactive and the teams who's working on WWZ, I‚Äôll be buying every new DLC that they release to support them, the game is a 10/10 Horde Zombie Coop Shooter.

Question‚Ä¶.. How the f*ck a 2019 Left 4 Dead Imitator got so much support than a 2021 Left 4 Dead Spiritual Successor, i.e. Back 4 Blood??, what the f*ck??.

Don't pay full price.

I first played WWZ when it was free on Epic Games, enjoyed it, kept up with it, then switched upon its 2021 Steam release. This isn't a game I take too seriously. It's one of those that we return to when the game updates (or if we're feeling like playing horde mode).

PROS ~ Great zombie fun with good friends. Probably the true L4D2 successor. If you like L4D, you'll probably like WWZ. The massive zombie hordes are unique to WWZ and you'll have fun nuking literal waterfalls of them. I refuse to play with public lobbies and will only play with my usual gaming squad.

CONS ~ Low playerbase. The bots can be awesome sometimes, but then they will quickly make up for it by ticking you off. I'd only bother with WWZ if you have 2-3 friends to play with (I play 4-player or 3 player + 1 bot often and we rarely have issues with just the one bot). Game is a bit graphically buggy when you're in a long session. The only game-ruining bug is that sometimes one of my squad gets kicked when we're in a session together. Happens most often in Horde Mode but has happened in the campaign too.
Game is broken as of now, matchmaking is completely broken. You'll find yourself in different region most of the time resulting in high ping.

This is an edited review because my first one did not do this game justice. 
I want to start this review by saying that World War Z is by far my favorite game. I just absolutely love it.
World War Z is a game that lets you play scenarios of how countries handled the outbreak, with the respected teams from each country. You can play Cooperatively or Solo. Bots do fill in the empty teams slots. The Bots have been improved drastically, they can finally use equipment or have a class selected for them. There are 3 different game mode, Coop Campaign, Horde Mode and Online PVP. There is replay value as for there are 8 classes that you can choose from a level up. To spice things up if they do get boring, you can play with moderators that add little challenges to the missions you play. There are Document collectibles that you can find in those special moderator maps, that once you've found them all give you bonus for the respected mission.
Now on to the part that's not great about this game. Saber are the not the best developers when it comes to constantly updating and adding things to their game. They are a bit slow but stuff still does get added and it still gets updates, just not as often as it should to keep a huge player base. The player base is basically die hards and people who use xbox gamepass (Gross). If you are looking for a mindless shooter with reply value and still gets new content occasionally then please try this game
If you have a blood lust for killing Zombies,  This is the game for you,  In my opinion this is the best Zombie killing game so far

Fast paced but still strategic. Very skill based but a smart player can always get the upper hand. Balanced weapons and abilities. There is a play style for everyone from "campers" to "run-n-gun". You can choose more support abilities too if that is your niche. I've played this game for years on Xbox/PS. This game never disappoints after a long day at work. The campaign is simple but there is a lot of lore and heartfelt moments. Mixed in with epic titan moments and a perspective of what it means to be a grunt in a multi-planetary war. The co-op vs AI is actually challenging, fun, and very useful to teach and improve your titan skills. This game is very rewarding, try it out, play to have fun and you will find a new gem in your collection. Seek out the Titanfall community, everyone is awesome and the love for this game is strong after many years

The mechanics behind the zombie rats make the game unplayable.
If you are not aware, rats are a special type of enemy which cannot be killed by anything which does not create fire. A LOT of fire. Basically, they are unkillable unless you horde very specific but rare weapons.

Until this mechanic changes, *do not buy.* The devs witter on about using flame throwers (rare and little ammo) without acknowledging the rats are a stupid game breaking mistake. If your teammate is pinned by rats, the only way to kill the rats is to kill your teammate. In other words, you leave them behind or attract the rats to you AFTER they have killed your teammate. 

TL;DR - game is close to zero fun but made irritating by the zombie rat mechanics.

So I purchased this game a few months ago because I was getting extremely board of Star Ship Troopers Extermination. I watched several people play this game on twitch and though hell with it. Now yes I have to say the game has its positive and negative about it. The fun side about it is when you just want to go around killing zombies or have had a bad day in real life you can get on here and take it out on the zombies. However the negative side of the game is the repeating maps and missions. One thing I have noticed and I really wish they would allow it is the ability to kick a person from the lobby without having to vote to kick someone. As a lobby leader I feel that if I create a lobby I should have the ability to kick who I want when I want without having to vote on who I want gone. When it comes to playing with friends it is ok but the game needs to be updated with new maps and weapons and zombies and such. The content is getting so boring that I have started to give up on the game because a person can play a game only so much before you just can not play anymore.

I recently plunged headfirst into the chaotic world of World War Z, and let me tell you, it's not just the un-dead I'm fighting ‚Äì it's discrimination! I don't know if the zombies attended a "How to Pick Your Targets" seminar, but it seems they've got a serious grudge against yours truly.

From the very beginning, it became painfully obvious that the undead have a beef with me specifically. I'll be strolling through the virtual apocalypse with my friends, cracking jokes and thinking I'm the cool hero of the story, when suddenly, I become the undead's designated snack. Seriously, it's like they have a group chat where they decide, "Let's go for the guy with the charming personality and a slightly slower sprint."

My friends? They're practically invisible to the zombies. It's like the undead have a strict diet plan, and I'm the only one on the menu. Meanwhile, my buddies are casually sipping virtual sodas and exchanging banter as if they're on a leisurely stroll through a zombie-themed park.

I've tried everything to blend in with the background ‚Äì crouching, running in zigzags, even attempting to disguise myself as a zombie (I might have overestimated the effectiveness of a limp). But nope, the zombies have my number, and it's on speed dial.

The worst part is, my friends find it absolutely hilarious. They're doubling over with laughter while I'm fending off more zombies than a horde at a "Brains All You Can Eat" buffet. I've become the comedy relief of the apocalypse, the guy who's one zombie bite away from a virtual re-spawn.

Despite the relentless targeting, I must admit it adds a layer of unexpected humor to the game. Sure, I might be the undead's favorite chew toy, but at least I'm providing my friends with endless entertainment. If World War Z ever introduces a "Most Likely to Become Zombie Chow" award, I've got it in the bag.

In conclusion, World War Z is not just a game; it's a lesson in humility. If you're looking for a challenge and don't mind being the undead's version of a celebrity chef's special, then step right up. Just be prepared to accept that in the zombie apocalypse, some of us are destined to be more buffet than survivor.

Here's my POV of comparing WWZ to B4B

+ Cheaper than Back 4 Blood
+ More enjoyable than Back 4 Blood (at least for me)
+ Better looting system than Back 4 Blood
+ Runs better than Back 4 Blood
+ Better atmosphere than Back 4 Blood
+ Characters interact with each other better than in Back 4 Blood
+ Smarter AI(s) than Back 4 Blood (they can carry the player at times)
- Although the AIs are smarter than Back 4 Blood, they are too dependent on the player. (AI(s) cannot pick up any items, cannot heal themselves, and keep moving when the player tries to heal them sometimes)
- Worse gunplay than Back 4 Blood
- You cannot jump
- Settings with a slider cannot be fine-tuned, they can only be increased or decreased by the increment of 1 (sensitivity, FOV, etc.)
- Sensitivity cannot be set low enough for low-sensitivity players
- You cannot move past a teeny tiny uneven surface every once in a while.

It's weird. This game went through a lot of stages and to be fair, I am surprised it survived this long.

Most the new content is just more grind, but sometimes we get new items, perks and some other neat stuff.

For a while the patches added new bugs and brought back the ones that were supposed to be "fixed". Lately it has been getting better though.

There is no information from the devs about the future of the game, after an update drops there's a long time of radio silence but for some reason new content (of which some is locked behind a paywall) still gets released.

[b]In conclusion[/b], it's a fun game that suffers from weird decisions from the devs and the lack of communication when it comes to the future of it.

This game wanted to be the new Left 4 Dead 2, and understandably so as L4D2 is straight iconic.

Unfortunately, it came out a few years too late to contend with that classic, along with parroting the gameplay of L4D2: Finding weapons around the map, following a linear map to another area, collect thing then use it elsewhere to progress mission, outlast hordes of infected until time runs out or they're all dead, special infected types (multiple types that pin/incapacitate you), etc.

This game had a lot of similarities to L4D2 (then again, I think any horde-shooter is bound to be compared to the God-tier classic that is L4D2), and it also has some originality: Characters have skills trees, different equipment types, you can upgrade weapons in the lobby, planting defenses before/during horde defenses segments, and some other stuff.

So just to summarize:

Pros: 
+Insanely huge hordes of infected
+Relatively newer game so graphics are fairly good
+Easy to learn
+Option to be Third Person Perspective or First Person Perspective (awesome)
+You can build defenses

Cons:
-It's basically the same as L4D2.
-Online community is either small or dead (good luck getting those pvp achievements)
-Generic special infected types
-The game has multiple mini-campaigns, however in total the game doesn't feel very long
-Levels are the same everytime

Conclusion: This game is OK. That's really all I gotta say about it. The huge sizes of hordes is breathtakingly awesome, to where everytime you see one you will hold your breath and question your capability to survive. If you want this game, wait for a sale.

- Intense and thrilling gameplay with a large number of zombies on screen at once

- Diverse range of levels set in different locations all around the world
- Solid sound design and soundtrack that enhances the immersive experience

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
- Lack of variety in missions and objectives can make gameplay feel repetitive after a while
- The game's AI can be glitchy at times, detracting from the immersion
- The storyline is somewhat predictable and doesn't offer anything particularly new or groundbreaking

A fun co-op zombie shooter game, if you liked L4D2, this game is very similar, while being more modern and offering more interested mechanics, like a class system with perks and special abilities, weapon customisation, and the ability to progress and improve your character(s).
The game is still supported by the devs after many years, with content being added once or twice a year, and bug fixes every couple of months. 
Note that this game is more complicated than L4D2, has a steeper learning curve, and is more challenging overall. It also requires more time investment to beat the top difficulty of the game.
The majority of players are on different platforms, as the game has crossplay, so do not be discouraged by the seemingly low players count on steam. People are very much playing this game, and you can find players to play with in minutes.
Overall a fun game, recommended to anyone who enjoys coop shooters.

UPDATE: Lost my saves when I reinstalled Windows. Saved Steam folder but I guess game info is on %AppData% which I did not save. RIP.

EDIT: They've fixed the main gripe I had with the game and that was not being allowed to use any character through all the missions. 

It's a decent 3rd person shooter. I got it on sale and it was probably borderline as to whether it was worth it or not. A lot of things I was expecting were actually not a thing in this game and so it made it less worth it than if they were actually a thing. 

 Things to know:
- [strike]You can't just choose one character and play through the whole story/campaign. You get 4 characters per area, i.e. New York, Japan, Moscow, etc., to choose from and that's it. When you get to a new area you have 4 new characters to choose from. Would've preferred to unlock characters as I went and been able to use them through the whole story/campaign.[/strike] It has since been added.
- You don't find weapons because you already have all of them. You just pay to unlock them as you play. And you can only unlock higher level weapons of the same type as you level your weapon.
- No exploration/discovery for maps. There is zero reason to explore maps. No weapons to find or characters to rescue. There are some kind of documents but I have yet to find any. I think you have to be on higher difficulty but not sure and don't really care personally.
- No real reason to be stealthy and go slow because you end up having to fight hordes at least 2-3 times per map. Plus, there is always someone or something making the docile zombies rampage.

Some things I did like were:
- I did like that I can choose any class for any character 
- The skill tree seems decent enough. 
- The game is voice acted so I love that.
- Can pick up any weapon you find so not locked into using only this weapon or that weapon for your class.
- Gun play feels good though not great.

Have played this game on Epic but moved to steam version recently.
The game offers a gripping and immersive experience that's sure to delight both fans of the series and newcomers, impressing with its intense cooperative action and strategic depth. Classes, abilities, and weapon upgrades add layers to game play, making teamwork essential, and the revamped melee system is a highlight, offering visceral satisfaction. The game also boasts stunning graphics with detailed environments and realistic character models, while its lighting effects and sound design create an atmosphere that draws players in.

While not groundbreaking, the narrative-driven campaigns provide a compelling backdrop to the action, immersing players in a globe-trotting journey to uncover the outbreak's mysteries. The game truly shines in its cooperative multiplayer mode, emphasizing teamwork and replay ability, thanks to the dynamic AI Director that keeps each play through fresh and exciting.

Offering diverse characters, satisfying combat, and stunning visuals, it's a must-play for fans and newcomers alike. It delivers adrenaline-pumping action and heart-pounding cooperative play in a post-apocalyptic world. Don't miss the chance to experience the Aftermath for yourself, embrace the chaos and survive the swarm ‚ò†Ô∏è.

[b]Looking for a fun L4D-like co-op game with some additions? Then this game might be for you.[/b]

World War Z is a L4D-like game, with some additions. There are special infected like in L4D, but what is missing is a more feared special infected like the Tank in L4D. The zombies act a lot like the zombies in the movie World War Z, where they form pyramids and climb on each other to get to different places. It's insanely satisfying to just blast away into the horde with heavy weapons when they do this.

There is a progression system in this game where you get to choose to play between 8 different classes that are good at different things. You can level up your classes to strengthen yourself and your team by unlocking perks. One class might be good at killing large hordes of zombies, while another is better at building defenses, etc. You can also level up all weapons to unlock attachments, such as silencers, skins and perks for your weapons. Once you have reached the max level of a class, which is lvl 30, you can also take prestige to unlock additional perks for the class.

The zombies AI is similar to L4D. They try to flank you, surround you, attack from behind, etc. If you're playing solo, you can choose to have bots on your team or play all by yourself. The behavior of the bots is similar to L4D, which is not always the best. I highly recommend playing with other players to get the best experience. It's not very easy to find players in matchmaking, but you can join the World War Z discord server to find people to play with if you don't already have a bunch of friends to play with.

The game has 5 difficulty levels. Easy, Normal, Hard, Insane and Extreme. The game has 4 episodes, with 3-4 chapters in each episode. If you own the DLC, there are 3 more episodes, making a total of 7 episodes. There is also Horde Mode where you have to survive 50 waves of zombies while building defenses etc. Silencers are strongly recommended on harder difficulty levels. It is also very fun and exciting to go stealth.

I think the replayability is good. There are Personal, Daily and Weekly challenges that rotate. Personal challenges can be to kill a certain amount of zombies with headshots, kill special infected in certain ways, and more. In Daily and Weekly challenges you replay random chapters with random mutators making the levels harder, where the Weekly is usually harder than the Dailys. Here you can only choose between Normal and Hard though, but it can be hard enough depending on which mutators are active. Higher difficulty give greater reward and xp, whether you play daily/weekly challenges or not. In any case, there are hundreds of hours to put into this game if you want to level up to max and unlock everything.

There is also a multiplayer mode where you play against other players in different game modes, while hordes of zombies periodically appear. However, multiplayer is almost completely dead, so finding a single match in matchmaking is very difficult, almost impossible. Eventually I managed to find a couple of games and try it out (always with the same players) and it was pretty fun.

There is one thing that is a bit annoying in this game, and that is the inability to jump. You can't jump in this game, but you can climb on things, such as cars and other things. If you then want to descend from the height you are at, you cannot fire or load your weapon while falling from this height to the ground. If you start a reload before you start falling, your reload will be interrupted in mid-air and you will have to reload again when you land.

[b]Overall, World War Z is a very fun co-op game if you have others to play with, and if so, I highly recommend giving it a try! 8/10. [/b]

[u]Updated on 25th August 2023[/u]

[u]Short Version:[/u]
I don't recommend buying this unless you have a group of friends that you know want to play it with you already. I like the setting and enjoy the game itself but it's main componant (which is multi-player/co-op) is now pretty close to non existant. It's almost as dead as it's own zombies, in other words. Many of the levels are dependant on having a team to play with. You can really only get so far with the AI meat shields :D Finding a match up, let alone a good one is a few and far between sort of event. Sometimes you'll get lucky and snag one quick. More often than not though you'll be lost at sea wondering just how far from the nearest coast you are.

[u]The not so short version:[/u]
Content wise, for this type of game, it's not really massively expansive. So far there's about 7 episodes with anything from 3-5 chapters each. You also get 8 different classes so if you want to level all of them up there's a fair amount of time you can burn on this game. The problem, really, is replayability. There's very little replay value once you've completed all of the episodes. The classes play different but like I said, it's finding a team that's the trick. co-op or multiplayer team finding can make an other wise one day task take 3-5 days because you'll be waiting to find teams so much. You can also play horde mode and horde mode xl. They're ok but similar to the call of duty survival matches, they can get boring pretty fast.

Once you've gone through all of the maps it's pretty much a rinse and repeat cycle. I expected as much when I bought it but god I didn't expect multiplayer to be this dead after only four years old (base game. Two if you count its main dlc; aftermath).

Edit: I actually found a slight work around for finding a team. Start from the episode you want and wait about 30-60 seconds. If you don't find a team, in that time frame, for your level then you can subsequently repeat the process on each episode, going backwards through the episodes. You'll find a team more often than not unless the gods of luck really hatin' on you.

Find a team somewhere using that method and if you're very lucky they'll eventually get to the episode you're after. Team retention is still a problem though and you'll be hard pressed to find a team that'll stick for more than a full episode. So finding friends you know wanna play is still your best bet. But at least some progression is viable now.

Edit: As pointed out by a commentator on my review, I have decided to add general area to my review.

I play from the general area of London, England, UK, Northern Europe. This should tell you just how bad it is. Since my region should be one of the most active regions in the entire world. Probably only second to North America and maybe some parts of Southern Europe.

Best zombie shooter or horde shooter game right now. 10 years ago, Left 4 Dead (L4D) was my favorite horde shooter game. I wasn't sure if a new generation of horde shooter game can ever top that. It turns out, World War Z delivered more than expected. The quantity of zombies are 2x-3x more  than what you see in L4D. They can stack up to climb high walls or high fences, just like in the movie. The AI of each zombie is siimilar to L4D. They will try to surround you, flank you, or get behind you.

There's also a progression system which made players stay addicted to the game. You can keep on upgrading your weapons and skills. There are many classes to choose from with their own perks and play style. There are tons of weapons to choose from. Each weapon does have its own feel to it.

There are also special zombies which exist in L4D. A police zombie which will run torwards you and pin you down. A Lurker which will hide and sneak up on you then leap and pin you down. There's a yellow zombie which can spread toxic gas and blur your vision completely. And there are more of them, including those that do not exist in L4D, such as the suicidal bomber, which will come near you and explode at you to do heavy damage.

You can also build defense structures, like auto turret, which will help you shoot hordes of zombies in different directions and electric volt, which will stun zombies on top of it.

So in short, it has far more rich content than L4D, hence its more fun. The only reason why some people haven't migrated to WWZ from L4D is because they still have low spec PC from a decade ago.

It's the "Left 4 Dead" that "Back 4 Blood" never was. It is not perfect, but it is a good spiritual successor.
Tip: turn on Crossplay to find game sessions quickly.

It's worth it on sale and with friends. The novelty of the big hordes doesn't last long. The fact that you stop gaining XP for your class once it hits 30 and you're basically punished for playing with it sucks. Characters are forgettable, explosives are underwhelming because they have a limit to how many zombies they can kill and there is a common bug where the lobby will never be emptied if people leave or disconnect. 
So for all you know you're playing alone when you'd think you're playing with 3 people, or the lobby will be hardlocked and you will never be able to actually start up a match until you leave the lobby and make a new one.

It's generic but G-spot is right on - the horde, and this could be positive, not to say the positive feedback and frequent updates made it worth. This game is the same quality level as B4B as i see, B4B is the one which focus heavily on official randomnizer stuff just like DBD but fighting with tons of zombies not 4 humans fighting with a murderer.

The developers have kept updating this game and its nice to know the game is still being looked after. Its really nice to see what you can do with minimal HUD, as the game is very intuitive (some areas aren't as tuned as others, but that is the nature of things). WWZ will never hold your hand and if you fail a map, you usually know why you failed most time. The agency the player has is what is so loved about this game. 

If I do have any criticism about this game, personally, is for WWZ to lean more into HUDless design. I'd like to see my side arm on my hip, my medkit and breach charges on my character or in/on my backpack; feels like lost potential. Skins and weapons that are previewed on in-game character backstories aren't available in game, and I feel juked. This is a very visual game, you could enhance the visual experience that much more.

Its fun to play, rewarding to understand, and has accessibility for all skill levels. Saber, please keep on rolling with the new weapons(repeating rifle is fire, needs skins) and hopefully more map content; if these are in the pipeline then idm buying dlc to support further WWZ Aftermath content.

Based on about 20 hours of solo play (although Steam says my game was running about 30 hours).

Playing solo on easy and normal difficulty so far, the game seems very good. Better than Killing Floor. The mechanics are a bit poorer than Left 4 Dead (for example, like Killing Floor there is a strength progression system for about six classes; there's even a progression system to level up your guns too) but the graphics and settings are so much more pleasant than either Killing Floor or Left 4 Dead. And it's fun to kill the big swarms, which seem like certain death, but rarely killed me (on easy difficulty). 

There are a few maps that are very frustrating for an inexperienced solo player, mostly because it's not obvious what one needs to protect - I failed on the first map of Tokyo about 8 times (again, on easy difficulty) before realising there were TWO gates I had to protect. The Kamchatka maps in the expansion are particularly bad at this: in one map, the game fails to tell you to hunt down the switches with the same labels on the bulletin board, and so I was lost there for about 15 minutes, not knowing what to do. At other times, I had difficulty protecting the Russian NPCs during swarm events because I didn't know where they were, and when I found them, I didn't know that there were TWO wire walls (on opposite sides of the building) where the zombies were breaking through. 

Another frustrating feature is the screamer zombie (which calls in more zombies until the screamer is killed). They can be very hard to locate, unless you are looking in the correct direction when they scream (one would expect an audio clue, but nope, it's visual). I think this would be a game breaking bug on higher levels, except that the screamers tend to stand and scream in the same 1-3 places with respect to one's current location, so experienced gamers have a good idea where to look as soon as the screaming starts.

All in all though, I enjoyed solo play in World War Z a bit more than early experience solo play in Left 4 Dead, and much, much more than any solo play in Killing Floor.

Looking through the global achievement numbers (Edit: whoops, I was an achievement requirement here. So instead I'll say: Kind of normal stats for a good game: 50% of players finished the first 4-map set (escape from New York), 28.4% finished all the maps (or maybe just the four map sets of the original game?), and 12% opened all skills in for one class, even the skills they were never going to use. Sadly, only 3% of purchasers marked at least 50 special zombies with the "mark" button.

My biggest tip is: gunslinger class is one of the best for solo play, but fixer and medic are both much better for multiplayer. I've been enjoying solo play, and maybe I'll max out my fixer before jumping into multiplayer. Apparently Discord is a good way to link up with other players. I guess I'll have to learn how to use Discord. Or maybe I'll wimp out and use the build-in matchmaker. That is rumored to have its own frustrations.

My thanks to I Love Lamp, who suggested I try the game out.
good game

After playing L4D2, Killing Floor 2, and Back 4 Blood... I will say that World War Z has been my most enjoyable zombies experience so far.

The classes and weapon progression maintain a simple and linear structure, yet the abundance of "perks" and "upgrades" allows for endless customization. The maps hold substantial replay value, each offering a unique experience. Additionally, the ongoing updates and DLCs that World War Z receives, even four years post-launch, bring a refreshing touch.

However, one aspect deserving criticism is the in-game currency system and the pace of progression. The prevalence of players at maximum Level 999 who've resorted to downloaded save states from others to unlock all content is noteworthy.

Overall, the final review stands at 9/10. It's a game that invites you to turn your brain and dive into a thrilling zombies pew-pewing experience.
fantastic horde shooter. Gun play is satisfying, sound is done very well, and the swarms feel intimidating. Variety of classes keep game play fresh, with optional Co-Op also functioning excellently.

The game is fun but has a few larger issues. I will speak of the issues I take with the game first. 
[h1] Early Game Grievances [/h1]
The early and late game both feel dissatisfying for different reasons. The early game nothing feels special about until you start unlocking perks for whichever class you are playing which isn't an issue for long but made it harder to initially get my friends into it. As well the difficulties don't feel well balanced where anything below three skulls is absurdly easy and at four skulls and higher felt much harder with certain maps making things harder or easier as well. 
[h1] AI Grievances [/h1]
Before I can explain the issues with the late game I must explain the problems with the AI. The AI simply can't replace actual people. The bots cannot use defenses, gather anything, use higher tier weapons, or level up alongside you. For these reasons you have to play more less on your own o higher difficulties, which is what you must play in the late game. 
[h1] Late Game Grievances [/h1] 
The late game is simply too much of a grind. On the easier difficulties you don't earn enough credits to prestige classes and level up weapons without a serious grind though I learned of an easier grind for credits and XP. [spoiler] playing Marseilles on 5 skull and dying at the first horde event. [/spoiler] The issue is that it doesn't give any blue credits which are required for some of the better weapon perks. On the topic of weapon perks to even be granted the option to purchase some weapon perks you must collect documents which can only be gotten 1/3 of a piece at a time on the randomized daily challenges. As I said, a major grind. 
[h1] Enjoyable Bits [/h1]
The hordes and zombies in general are phenomenal to watch run, pile up and break through defenses. It also feels great gunning down those same hordes. Each class does feel unique and fun as you level them up. The campaign is fun to play through the first few times and has enough variety between the episodes to allow each to feel unique despite following the same general formula. I think the game can be fun alone but is much better enjoyed with friends and do recommend it. 6.5/10

Practice offline to master the combat mechanics and avoid being the person who is lost in the midst of action. The game offers a strong Left 4 Dead vibe, and its classes are what contribute to the enjoyment. Teamwork is crucial for tackling higher difficulty levels. Just be a team player. If there's a medic on your team, be considerate and avoid hastily grabbing medkits or the final equipment bag. Most classes have a equipment bag re-spawn.

Pros:
- Simple and addicting gameplay
- Classes (different gameplay per class)
- Graphics and atmosphere with so many story telling details
- Guns feel right and many to choose from
- Each map has different vibes
- Game modes: Solo/Coop Campaign | Horde Mode | PVP (dead mode)
- Many characters to choose from
- Improved bots for beginners and solo players (*THIS IS NEW UPDATE)
- Mutators
- FPS (for guns)
- Surprise big updates
- Nice community

Cons:
- Bugs 
- Sudden disconnections
- Lobby bug (when someone leaves, player is still "there" hence no one can replace him/her)
- Annoying specials (Quick respawning lurkers, Rats, Booster)
- FPS (melee shifts to TPS - disorienting) 
- Lack of communication from devs (we don't know if they are still updating the game or done with it)
- Surprise big updates (takes like 2 years)

*NOTE TO BUYERS:
- Buy World War Z: Aftermath or Deluxe Edition for better experience.
- Buy World War Z only if you don't mind having no access to 3 chapters (France, Rome, Kamchatka) and FPS mode

Overall:
I have been playing this game for 2 years now and it earns my positive review.  With the current update, the game feels fresh for me.  The game is easy to pick and have fun.  I highly recommend this game if you are looking to fight zombie massive swarm with friends or solo.

I was sceptical starting this game for the first time. I don't normally play online only games anymore, I lost the taste for it. WWZ definitely isn't online only, but for a easier and more fun playthrough, the game is actually amazing! The game perfectly captures what the movie was like. I do believe this game takes place after the movie the game is based on. I honestly prefer the movie version of the Zekes than the book version as the movie version are more terrifying to me. How they sprint without stopping, climbing on top of each other as fast as they possibly can, not even wanting to eat you, simply to infect you only. Of course for a game they can't just one hit kill you, so instead they have to beat you until you drop.
The soundtrack is pretty good, and the maps are creative, the game makes a massive first impression in the first campaign level, watching a ocean of zekes running down the street across from the building you're watching from is scary and awesome! Not to mention it foreshadows what's coming. The best part about this game is the horde moments in levels and the horde mode itself. Watching them like ants just sprinting in your direction, sent a chill down my spine the first time I saw it. I think the only complaint I actually have with the game is that there's not enough outfits for each character. I think only half or maybe less of the characters have an alternate look, and every character has a recolour of their default look with maybe a accessory added on or swapped. Really would prefer more looks for the characters and backstory videos for all the characters, only about half of them have those as well.
Other than that, I really do like World War Z.

Plagued by technical issues (gamepad and steamlink). It was a nightmare to make this work with a gamepad; in windows 11 latest drivers and everything ONLY this game has issues with xinput. It is extremely picky. It only worked after I used DS4windows.exe to FORCE xinput on top of my default xinput (nintendo switch pro) controller that works perfectly fine to play other games such as Elden Ring and even controls the operating system natively by itself. 

Steamlink: nightmare as well. Since it has the above issue it doesn't natively support xbox-official peripherals like the Gamesir x2 pro Xbox edition. Again, all other games I have work perfectly fine but NOT this one. 

In order to make it work I had to use steam's settings and force a keyboard WASD+Mouse emulation on top of the controls (which work fine on the overlay by default, but not in this game).

Finally, it Steamlink does NOT work if this game is using Vulkan graphics engine instead of DirectX 11. 

This was the only game on my entire library that had me working 2h~3h to simply make it playable on PC with a gampad and also via steamlink. Ah, it also doesn't work on GeForce now with a gamepad so it is completely unplayable on a gamepad on GeForce as far as I know.

I'm not refunding it because I will not give up the time I invested into working around all these issues and the game itself seems fine (I had already played it in the past on Xbox Cloud).

I'd like to mention that these gamepad issues seem to have been reported since 2020 in the previous versions of this game and the publisher apparently did NOTHING to address these issues. Terrible support I guess.

World War Z is a zombie survival game, takes place in the context of zombies dominating the world and "Aftermath" is an expansion pack with many notable additions to the co-op shooter. It added two new levels Rome and Kamchatka. Each level continues to be divided into three different chapters like the old episodes, but still has the same task requirements as what you experienced in the original game. Much of it revolves around defending the base and escorting the NPC to the gathering point. The quest design has not improved from before, especially the Rome stage, more or less leaving me a little disappointed because of this.

Although the amount of new content is not too massive, this expansion still adds some interesting gameplay updates, making it more challenging and diverse than the original. Notably, the option allows players to switch back and forth between first and third person in the game experience. However, this feature is designed quite  "half-heartedly",  so it still feels a bit 'pretentious'. Specifically, the scope of most weapons becomes useless when experienced in first-person perspective. This is very evident when you let the character sit and shoot, the feeling is no different from the character when standing and shooting when compared to the experience of any FPS game. 
The game also have some miscellaneous bugs related to the behavior of the zombies. The 'force feedback' feature of the handle also does not convey the feeling of experience well. The most obvious is when performing "bull butt", Vanguard character class players do not feel the ironing power of the electric shield, so it is difficult to know if the attack hit the enemy or not.

In overall from my point of view: This is a good game, things i love about the game is the survival horde mode, it can up to 3 hours of playing and the weapon + player class "ability".  BUT compare with the game made by Valve,  [b] i'll give this 7/10 [/b].  
Personally i [u]don't recommend[/u] this game due to the game + DLC price, we can still have lots of other better games with better price

TL;DR - Buy with Aftermath DLC with or without sale, game is worth its full price. Avoid if going only for base game regardless of sale. Buying with friends recommended, solo buyer looking for multiplayer not ideal unless you're okay with spending some time leveling alone first before heading into multiplayer.

IMPORTANT NOTE: If you're going into this game solo hoping for an alive online play, I suggest reconsidering firstly. The "veterans" will outright leave your lobby if they see that you are low level. This is most likely due to horrible practice that shockingly many YouTuber that were World War Z focused, pushed. They all pretty much emphasized on leaving lobbies with lower level players to "not waste time" and personally I've experienced this despite not being completely new to this game. Essentially, if you are solo looking for an online scene, you'd need to play solo with bots first to gain some levels before "veterans" will want to stick around your lobby. At least this game supports full crossplay though, with Epic, Microsoft Windows Store(Game pass), Xbox and PlayStation so you will likely always find players.

As a double dipper of this game (owned this on the PS4 back in 2019) and having finally finished all the DLC Aftermath has to offer, I'm confident to say that I can still recommend this game.

I'm sure you've heard this comparison before if you've ever looked up "Left 4 Dead 3" but World War Z is pretty much the Left 4 Dead 3 that never was. Its a great zombie shooter that focuses on MASSIVE hordes of zombies. Its even got its own kind of special infected too but they are miles more annoying than L4D1/2's and some are less balanced than others. Great selection of guns too but a meh progression built for it. Who's silly idea was it that you cannot level up your guns if you dont unlock the next level? This wouldnt be a flaw if the game was generous or reasonable with its ingame currency but they pay you in peanuts even in the higher difficulties. Dont even let me start with the challenge coins. The amount given for both currency are pitiful.

Overall, I'd say only pick this game up with Aftermath DLC. If you can only go for the base game, I suggest waiting for a sale with the DLC or dont bother because without Aftermath DLC, you would be missing out on a lot of content.

The game is pretty much still alive too with weekly and daily challenges along with it still being updated by the developers. As a vanilla player back in 2019, the most notable changes are being able to play whatever character you want regardless of which campaign map you're on, a reworked weapon progression system whereby attachments are just cosmetics now instead of functional and a first person mode (although this is DLC locked) and many more.

World War Z delivers a pulse-pounding and action-packed experience that immerses players in the midst of a global zombie apocalypse. With its relentless hordes of undead, dynamic gameplay, and cooperative multiplayer, this game successfully captures the chaos and thrill of surviving against overwhelming odds. If you're a fan of intense zombie shooters, World War Z is a must-play title that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

One of the standout features of World War Z is the sheer scale of zombie hordes it throws at you. From the narrow streets of New York City to the rooftops of Tokyo, the game presents relentless waves of undead that will test your shooting skills and strategic thinking. The swarming zombies create a palpable sense of tension and urgency, and the game's impressive AI ensures that no two encounters feel the same. Whether you're mowing down zombies with heavy weaponry or holding your ground against a seemingly endless horde, the intensity of the gameplay is unmatched.

The cooperative multiplayer mode in World War Z adds an exciting layer of teamwork and coordination to the experience. Team up with friends or other players online to fight back against the zombie onslaught, sharing resources, covering each other's backs, and strategizing to survive. The game offers a variety of missions and objectives, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging as you progress through different locations and face increasingly challenging scenarios.

Visually, World War Z is impressive, with detailed and atmospheric environments that capture the devastation and chaos of a zombie-infested world. From the eerie darkness of underground tunnels to the crumbling cityscapes, each level is crafted with attention to detail, creating an immersive and visually stunning experience. The audio design also deserves praise, with chilling sound effects and a haunting soundtrack that enhance the sense of danger and immersion.

The game's arsenal of weapons is diverse and satisfying to wield. From traditional firearms to heavy weapons and explosive ordnance, the selection of armaments caters to different playstyles and provides a satisfying array of options for dispatching the undead. Upgrades and customization options allow you to fine-tune your loadout to suit your preferred playstyle, adding depth and personalization to the gameplay.

While the game's focus on fast-paced action and hordes of enemies is its strength, it also means that the storytelling and character development take a backseat. The narrative is primarily a backdrop for the intense gameplay, and the characters may not leave a lasting impression. However, the game's focus on intense action and cooperative play more than compensates for this.

In conclusion, World War Z offers an intense and thrilling zombie shooting experience that will keep you hooked from start to finish. With its relentless zombie hordes, cooperative multiplayer, and impressive visuals, the game delivers a high-octane and immersive gameplay experience. If you're a fan of zombie shooters and enjoy the thrill of surviving against overwhelming odds, World War Z is a game that will keep you entertained and coming back for more chaotic zombie-slaying action.

It's been a while since I've reviewed a game, so I am going to keep this short and sweet....

Pros: Zombies, third-person shooter, simplistic yet challenging, intense horde mechanics, and excellent for those who prefer online play. 

Cons: Lackluster level progression schemes, on rails, no real customization away from pre-rendered skins, and is most certainly, "Better with friends."

My biggest gripe with the game is going to be that they didn't flesh out the levels, but instead created a series of extremely condensed environments where the only time spent there is extended through contrived, "search, activate, fight the horde," loops. 

I spend most of my time in-game attempting to locate keys and switches in low-light environments, all the while I'm waiting for the next horde to inevitably show up and make my nearly-blind search that much more of a chore. 

This game is definitely worth it on a sale, it's splendid for what it tried to be, but the contrived game play loop in every condensed section of every map is really killing it for me.

I can't fathom the positive reviews of this game. If you want to play a good version of this play L4D2, even as old as it is it is a much better/polished game. WWZ is, in all aspects, extremely mediocre. It's not terrible and not great, just midling. It's buggy as all get out, and has massive grind layered over the top for no good reason.


Gameplay:
WWZ gameplay is ok. It's a basic zombie shooter cloned from L4D with specials that mimic the specials in L4D and a singular unique mechanic of zombies building on top of each other to climb walls.  The weapons are ok, the maps are ok, the strategies are ok.

Placing defensive items is both interesting and frustrating as you can only place them in pre arranged spots and in many cases they face in different directions (your oprions) and you never know what direction the horde will come from so it feels a bit forced, rather than being able to place them anywhere or even reposition them.

They don't allow you turn off Friendly fire separate from the difficulty level. In my view this is a mistake made by many games FF should always be a checkbox separate from the difficulty. We want to play at the max difficulty but lag and other things like the bugs (described below) make Friendly Fire idiotic.

Bugs:
I only play MP with 3 other freinds for a team of 4. None of us can walk up stairs in this game, or over train tracks or over anything else on the ground. You stop as if you hit an invisible wall. Running, or couching and uncrouching your way up the stairs can usually get you up but it happens routinely and I can't fathom why it would not have been fixed by now.

Other players also routinely turn invisible. In our playthroughs basically at all times, at least one player can not see one other player. Someone is always invisible to someone until them pick up something (medkit) or interact with something and then they pop back, but interacting can also turn your invisible, so it's a rotation of who can't see who, and sometimes you can't see multiple players. Fairly gamebreaking in a zombie shooter with Friendly Fire that can't be turned off.

Grind:
This is perhaps the worst part of the game and pushes this review into negative territory. The game introduces XP and leveling of your character and weapons. As you play you gain XP to level your character and XP to level each gun you use (you pick up random guns during the game and don't generally start with the one you may want to use). There are three tiers of weapons. 

Each time you level a weapon (or your character) you have to pay money to buy the level, even though you just got enough XP to get it. If you don't buy the level of the gun... you STOP gaining further XP until you do buy it. You can not earn enough money to raise 3 guns (one in each weapon tier) and your character. Therefore you are wasting XP, also you can't delay deciding what gun you want to spend money on since you will not be gaining XP for it.

To get money you have to play ridiculous challenge maps and modes that are simply not fun and grind out the money you need, but you will also gain levels doing this. There is no way to smoothly play through the campaign and raise even one on gun at each tier never mind trying some of the others. 

Not worth it at all. Play L4D2 again, or Dying Light, or any other decent zombie game out there.

Once I figured out how certain things varied from Left4Dead, and then upped the difficulty to at least level 3, the game became a lot more fun.  The horde fights, or even just the smaller hordes drawn by screamers, end up being life or death battles.  In L4D you can mostly gather in a corner and shove and shoot through a horde until the tank comes.  In WWZ you need to keep your feet moving, but still keep your team in site and protected, or you‚Äôll be quickly overwhelmed.  The stealth possibilities, headshotting a hallway of zombies with silenced weapons, is fun too but rare in matched games where someone is always shotgun happy.

Anyway, game is totally entertaining and I‚Äôm sad to see the low review scores.  It is a lot like Left4Dead 3 might have been, minus the first person view.  No shoving though, just slicing and chopping which is admittedly more fun.

Oh boy, where do I even begin with World War Z? This game is like a whirlwind of chaos and laughter, with a side of mindless zombies for good measure. I haven't had this much fun since my grandma mistook the TV remote for a cookie and tried to take a bite out of it. But hey, let's not forget to address the elephant in the room - the discord community.

Now, World War Z itself is a thrilling ride. You team up with friends, unleash an arsenal of weapons, and mow down hordes of undead like you're playing a high-stakes game of lawn darts. The action is fast-paced, the levels are diverse, and the zombies...oh boy, these zany zombies will have you in stitches!

But when it comes to the discord community, let's just say it's like entering a zombie-infested party where everyone's trying to outdo each other in the toxic dance-off. Now, don't get me wrong, there are some genuinely great people there who are more than happy to lend a helping hand or share a hilarious meme. However, there's a small but vocal minority who seem to have a case of the undead grumpies.

You'll encounter a few individuals who take themselves way too seriously, spewing negativity faster than a zombie losing his dentures. It's like they've forgotten that this is a game, not a battle for world domination. But fear not, my fellow survivors, for every toxic troll, there are ten times more friendly faces who will gladly take you under their wing and show you the ropes.

In fact, I've found that the best way to deal with the discord negativity is to fight back with laughter. Share your funny in-game moments, crack jokes, and remind everyone that we're all here to have a good time. Trust me, when you make a fellow player snort coffee through their nose with your witty banter, it's a true victory against the discord undead!

So, while the toxic zombies may be lurking in the discord community, don't let them dampen your spirits. World War Z is a riotously fun game that will have you laughing and screaming in equal measure. Grab a group of friends, form your own zombie-killing squad, and let the good times roll. After all, laughter is the best antidote to any toxic outbreak!

This game is super-fun for us two old guys playing together casually twice a week an evening some co-op games. All difficulty levels and maps can be played with two human players (or more) while adding bots as friends (in total four slots in the team). Those bots are of cause not as sufficient as human players, but they do their job as bait and by rescuing us.
The maps are very diverse and behave different regards spawn points for lots each time you play them.
There is a high replayability since we are highly motivated in gaining better weapons and classes for taking the challenge on a higher difficulty level, which has been lots of fun so far.
I have pretty average hardware since I am not spending crazy A$1K for a new graphic card, also my CPU is very average. The game still performs fine, even while I am using higher settings than recommended. Which is quite astonishing having in mind that hundred or more Zombie bots attack in waves at once.
A minor mishap is the game not closing on my W11 PC, so the task manager is your friend.
And I wish that the developer would provide $10 DLCs with about five maps being added into the campaign's flow coz such would increase the replayability even more.

In short: I love this game.

I love your game. It's fun. Extremely fun. If only it wasn't full of so many bugs that just make it impossible to play. I can't pull several of my friends away from Left4dead to play this because we can't even get into matches without them DC'ing or just being able to not connect ever. That's just one of them, but the most important issue.
Why would I or my friends play this over other older and similar titles when they work and this doesn't?

The game is great with friends and the difference in how the guns feel is satisfying but I will say the bots are not  decent in the slightest, they on rare occasions are the most broken thing I have ever seen as they survive punishment that a fully maxed out character of yours dies to in seconds for a minute, teleport to get you back up right before you die from the otherside of the map , or kill specials in a single shot. However the amount of times you run into this is trivial compared to how bad they actually are. Most similar games I have played, Left for dead 2, Vermontide 1 and 2 The A.I. levels up based on either weapons found throughout the game, or by perks that you have chosen for those characters or classes you've played as. WWZ does not have this, they remain level one gunslingers and do not switch out starting level weapons for any upgraded ones found. They also will not pick up any equipment, health items or defense kits where as in the previous stated games they will switch out both weapons and grab any gear you do not until they all have their equipment/health item and defense/bomb/ect slot filled. Over all a pretty good game but play with friends not alone. 4/5
