For the record, I have a whole boatload of gaming experience. Most current gamers were prolly not even born yet when I started gamin' <smirk>. So, yes, I have a life and tens of thousand of gaming hours.

 In my opinion, this is currently not worth buying unless its WELL over 50% off, because people drop this game due to frustration with daily and weekly challenges, and ludicrous ace-busting carrot chasing "blue coins". 

This game is simple for most people, but if you plan on NOT cheating and try to platinum this game, it becomes frustrating. Documents to get a single gun is not worth it. Neither are frustrating yourself with crappy modified players who have no IDEA what strategy is and run off with their pants on fire, with no way to KICK these idiots.

I have found NO ONE communicates via voice on this game, other than my gaming partner. 

Zombies spawn in previously cleared ares? Yes, lots of them. Realistic, ummm NO.

Reaction time favors the zombies, even if you are a religious reloader like me, they will win.

Electric fence grids are nice, but they are zombie magnets. Even if our Team gets the idea the  zombie is dead by electrocution and bullets, it sits on the grid, chewing away valuable points. 
Yeah, we tear them apart to help save resources.

it seems an heavily unfair advantage goes to zombies in horde mode because "resources" bongo bucks to purchase supplies gets less and less after wave 30? WHY is that?  Cuz....
I guess being part of HUMAN wasn't calculated into this equation... we are and DO make mistakes. Why penalize players by throwing more stuff at them with less bongo bucks?

BUT since it is NOT worthy to play over 30-35 waves, because once you hit the level 30 cap for that prestige level, the rest of your XP is trashed. So, quit in order to stop wasting your time and effort in horde.

To obtain a sword you need to play the hardest level. You read the words from the developers that paraphrased seem to indicate your chances to succeed are zilch. Most "carrots" are the same way. 

IMHO, CROSSPLAY purely sucks, but will be turned since people cannot be blocked or is RARE cases, friended if they are really talented gamers ( 2 in hundreds of players noted).

There are "carrots" within this game that "appear" to be game changers, probably allowing you to go a little farther than normal. BUT the objectives are riddled with 3-4 mutators when playing the daily and weekly challenges that are close to ludicrous. In order to platinum this game you need to get like 10,000 blue coins? COME ON. Who the hell comes up with these "restrictions" ?  isn't this supposed to be an enjoyable and fun game?? 

These blue coins are difficult for the average player to obtain. In my opinion, it is the developers way to ace bust the game. BUT there are trainers and cheat people use to get 999 levels and 99,999 blue coins, so lets have the cheaters benefit from this and the regular players suffer. Rich.....

If they would give you ONE blue coin per horde wave completed whether normal (1 coin) or hard (2 coins) , it MIGHT be worthy of trying to platinum this game. Most play it for as long as they can tolerate it, and flush it.

The "weekly challenges" are NOT worth playing . The restrictions they place on you by raising the difficulty level and throwing mutators on the missions makes it ludicrous to get blue coins and or documents.

[h1] What is This? [/h1]

To make it easy and Simple. If you've ever played [b] Left 4 Dead [/b] or any of games alike it, you will notice the similarities, just like many other Zombies games that features a four-player co-op history-mode.

Some missions may have a few different things from others, but in the end, the whole gameplay is the whole repetitive form of ... 

 [u] 1 [/u] -   [i] Go there! Get some weapons on the way, there [/i] 

[u] 2 [/u] - [i] You've Arrived! [/i] [b] NOW DEFEND THIS! [/b] 

[u] 3 [/u]  - [i] Good job, now thou hath  defended this, Haveth a few objectives for you, as you get some more supplies and weapons, on your way to the rest of the mission. [/i]

 and then it goes on Repeat-Mode, and you just repeat [u] 1 [/u] from [u] 3 [/u] , and sometimes you get to [b] ARM DEFENSES, TO DEFEND AGAIN! [/b] ---  [u] Wow, good job, you've finished the mission, now be ready, for the next mission will include exactly the same objectives, but a whole different layout-map~! [/u] 

[h1] Is The Game Any Way Related to The Movie? [/h1]

Sorry, fellow-movie-fan, It's the same Universe, Completely different history, to be fair, some of the logic of this game... I would even dare say, this is a whole different dimension too, that just happens to have the placeholder event of Zeke's  biting people's neck all over Earth or something.

[h1] What Else Should You Be Aware of?! [/h1]

The [b] A.I [/b] , it takes alot of patience and time to play and adjust together with the A.I, the A.I won't help you at all if you play a high difficulty mission, they take times to do alot of things, and sometimes they will completely forget they have to revive you, or any other of themselves. But they're damn good at shooting zombies, they're like human-like turrets, a shame we can't make them use specific weapons, they would destroy every single zombie!

[h1] Some Completely Unrelated Commentary that literally doesn't even make any Sense. [/h1]

Ah, yes... A game where... [u] Russians [/u] will speak [b] English [/b] with [i] Heavy Russian Accent [/i] to Other [u] Russians [/u], while being in [b] Russia [/b], for unclear reasons? [spoiler] Like, Broh, You're in the same country, you're all russian-speakers, why speak english to each other? Do you think the zombies even know language? [/spoiler]

While the game will also feature [u] Japanese [/u] Character who will simply, and mostly, just speak  [i] English with Heavy Japanese Accent [/i], while also being in [b] Japan [/b] and simply talking with other [u] Japanese [/u] who will also answer back in [b] English [/b]...  Excuse me, what?

This is by no doubt, a game made by Americans, I expected more Immersion,  from the Money I paid for, aside from all the Cool '' MOUNTAIN-CENTIPEPE-CASCADE'' Of zombies that pile up, just like in the movies!

But, yeah, no... Unfortunately, I had to bear with hearing people speak some tongue that it is not even native to them, and why would they speak it, with others that simply speak their original language and not speak it with them? Ugh, at least the [u] Combat System [/u] is good...
,

Alongside the [u] ''Graphics '' [/u] / [u] The Soundtrack [/u] / [u] The Horror Setting [/u] [spoiler] I love that little ''jumpscare effect'', so, yeah, beware, you can get spooked from this game [/spoiler] / and the [u] GunPlay and Mechanics [/u] are Impecable, and I think this game has it's own charm when it comes to it.


Still... Lacks immersion, but who am I kidding? This is just a videogame, not even real life...

Gets dull fast. If you want to kill zombies, play L4D instead. The only thing that was somewhat interesting was the class system, but even that was disappointing in the end, with it being so linear and unsatisfying. You could have special zombies that would be much easier to take down with specific classes, but there's simply no difference whichever class you pick. The potential is obvious but no capitalized upon, which is a shame.

There is ZERO reason to replay this game's campaign mode, and the characters are so generic and one dimensional that you will wish they would just die already.

 I assure you, after the first few levels, you'll be passively running through the campaign episodes while daydreaming about a different game or what you're gonna have for dinner later.  

I was told to not rush through the levels and instead search for weapons and stuff in the environment, but what is the point when there will be the same, or even better weapons at the next checkpoint you run to? what kind of argument is that?. The weapons themselves are just mediocre and you won't even be compelled to upgrade them, cause it doesn't make a difference!.

There's just zero initiative to play this game over better, more fun zombie shooters like L4D, except for better graphics. This game also came out years after L4D yet doesn't really bring anything new to the table, which leaves me dumbfounded.  There is definitely fun to be had, just not for more than 2 hours or so. 

Ask yourself: Should I spend close to $30 bucks on a game with less content than a kindergarten point and click adventure, one dimensional characters that you wish would jump off a cliff,  a lack of any compelling plot whatsoever, narrow linear stale environments which all are the exact carbon copies of each other just with a different paint job, a dead online multiplayer and worthless player progression, or do I play a better game that is cheaper, way more interesting with loads more content and still boasts a huge community despite being more than a decade old?

so if "woohoo better graphics = great game" or if you're a brain-dead zombie that feeds off mediocrity,
give it a shot.

 But if you want to spend your hard earned money on something worthwhile, compelling and enjoyable for more than a couple of hours? give it a pass. In fact, go buy a pizza instead! way more satisfying.

An unpolished, entertainment-deficient blob that plays like it was originally made as a low-budget PS3 game. Missing any form of distinguishing traits to feel excited about returning to beyond the large hordes, which are still nothing special given it's not even fun to shoot them with your wimpy, boring weapons. If you're looking for a co-op zombie shooter, L4D2 holds up far better. If you're just looking for the largest zombie hordes possible, Days Gone offers comparable amounts of zombies to mow through alongside being a far better-controlling and better-designed game overall. WWZ, on the other hand, is not at all worth your time.

With friends I think its ok, but as a solo experience, its not great. This is definitely a "wait for a sale" kind of game imo. Coming from L4D and most other fps'/tps', movement feels weird. It has wonky momentum when changing directions rapidly.

 Aiming sorta feels like its emulating an analog stick onto a mouse, so there's this weird sudden stop and go with the speed at which the crosshair moves. It does not feel like using a mouse. I cant really explain this in better detail unfortunately.

It's a pretty good game, although i do feel like it can use some more diversity.
Also i really would have wished we had like a level that plays off in Jeruzalem like in the movie with the really big wall.
And if they added like: more talent tree upgrades, aiming down sight (with scopes), prehabs a story-mode survival play mode that is like the one in the movie and prehaps being a bit more forgiving towards solo players. 
I feel like that would improve the game a lot.

**NO SPOILERS**  (also have +100 hours played on PS4)

Very short version: yes the game is fun and worth the purchase.

Okay, so there is nothing to actually spoil. There is a few lines of dialogue to move things along but in terms of a story? There is not much of one. That's not the reason you would want to play this game anyway. For a direct comparison this is basically a third person Left 4 Dead 2.

Graphically the game gets it done. Not groundbreaking but certainly very pretty at times. What steals the show though is the size of the zombie hordes. They are absolutely massive especially when you get to higher levels in of horde mode. Levels are mostly linear but can have areas to explore and made in such a way that I often forgot that they actually were linear.

Control are simple and precise with either mouse and keyboard or controller. There aren't an overwhelming amount of keys to assign. It would have been completely unnecessary in such a game.

Lastly, the Aftermath edition is worth the extra money. You get additional episodes, horde mode and the ability to play the game in first person. The only issue I have is that in first person mode there is no actual ADS but only a simple zoomed view of the weapon so scopes and sights are all but non functional except on two sniper rifles.

Hardware: Predator Helios 300 with 1660ti
Graphical Settings: Ultra and it runs without so much as a hiccup. 

** Something unexpected was being able to play completely offline. Internet was out for a week but was still able to play and progress.

Overall, a fun game. As expected, it is only loosely World War Z (there's a bunch of zombies around the world), but it does follow different characters in different areas with different goals so it does somewhat capture the spirit of the book.  
+ Difficulty scaling seems to be pretty good, so easy is actually easy and you can choose harder if you want
+ Weapon upgrading is a fun mechanic 
+ Class skills are enjoyable to choose, though some are obviously better than others
+ Mutators to change things up (though most of these are about making the game harder, it could do with more directly beneficial ones and/or amusing mutators)
+ Maps look excellent
? The game really likes swarms suddenly running in as you wander about. L4D2 did more of a 'there are a bunch of zombies already waiting in the level', while this has that, most of the enemies you face while walking around are ones which rush in.
? The game really likes areas where you have to defend against large swarms. There's at least 2 every mission. Place some defenses, try to defend a specific place which is for some reason attracting zombies (sometimes this makes sense due to a large noise, sometimes you're left questioning as to why hundreds of zombies are rushing this area). This isn't bad, but it does feel overdone. L4D2 did this more often just at the very end of a level.
- The game appeared to give some upgraded versions of weapons at the start? I don't know if this is DLC or just things they've added after the game has been out for a time, but they tend to be better than the default ones for that level. This makes so you basically skip a couple levels of a weapon, which is weird.
- There's no (notable) modding or custom maps, and you can get through all the maps in ~12 hours (probably shorter if you really try, or longer if you take your time on harder difficulties).
- It feels too easy to get most of the weapons? 
- There's 'blue coins' for accessories which you get from completing challenges, but with how few you get via just playing the game rather than focusing on challenges, you probably won't get any accessories for the characters without essentially playing through the game repeatedly. As well, since the missions have a different set of four characters each time (except for the Japan and last Russia mission, though I don't know if they get the same accessories since they're treated as different characters elsewhere) then you won't be having them a lot of the time.

The game is fun, but I'm not certain I'd suggest paying the current $40 for it. It has some issues in polish (though the maps are beautiful, I'm referring to gameplay) and notable issues in how much replayability there is or will be.

Llevo jugando WWZ desde Marzo 2020 en Epic Games y tuve que comprarlo en Steam por preferencia en la plataforma, por ello es que dejar√© mi opini√≥n sobre la actualizaci√≥n de Aftermath (nuevos mapas, nueva clase Vanguardista y m√°s) en vez del juego completo.

Mapas:
La verdad que me encantan, el equipo de Saber ha desarrollado muy bien nuevas mec√°nicas incorporadas en los nuevos mapas (Roma y Kamchatka). Me hubiera gustado que hubieran m√°s catacumbas al estilo de Marsella, pero es preferencia personal. El elemento de perder vida por las bajas temperaturas en Kamchatka es incre√≠ble, en mi opini√≥n ha sido perfectamente implementado y espero se apliquen nuevos elementos atmosf√©ricos que involucren nuevas estrategias de juegos en futuras actualizaciones.

Clase Vanguardista:
En mi opini√≥n la nueva clasde es bastante mediocre, es superada por cualquier otra clase support (M√©dico, Maestro de Drones y Manitas). El √∫nico momento en donde brille y sea bastante √∫til es por disminuir el tiempo de espera en reaparici√≥n de un personaje cuando es eliminado; sin embargo, con la presencia de un M√©dico o Manitas o un Drone que te protege de zombies cercanos, morir es casi imposible cuando se trata de jugadores con experiencia.

Ratas:
Me gusta que aporta un trabajo en equipo para poder deshacerse de ellas en caso alguien sea deshabilitado, adem√°s de forzarte a usar armas pesadas o inclusive el lanza llamas, que anteriormente era muy infravalorado por muchos jugadores nuevos. En un inicio eran bastante dif√≠ciles de eliminar, pero no imposible; sin embargo, por bastantes quejas de jugadores al no encontrar posible forma de matarlas, las nerfearon a tal punto que ahora, en mi opini√≥n, son inservibles, muy f√°ciles de matar.

Cosm√©ticos:
Agregaron dos nuevos llaveros, un mando de PS y una bocina peque√±a. No son nada impresionante, pero dan m√°s motivos de querer adquirir nuevas monedas azules. Tambi√©n agregaron nuevas apariencias a los personajes de Marsella, los cuales son incre√≠bles, en especial el de Eloise. Obviamente tras la aparici√≥nn de los nuevos mapas hay nuevos personajes en Roma que ya vienen tambi√©n con apariencias para desbloquear, pero lamentablemente solo 3 por cada personaje en vez de 4. Los personajes de Kamchatka son los mismos que los de Tokyo, pero con atuendos de invierno.

Por √∫ltimo la nueva mec√°nica de combate cuerpo a cuerpo es incre√≠ble, hay para todos los gustos y colores, desde armas ligeras hasta pesadas, dependiendo del estilo de juego de cada uno. Adem√°s que cada arma cuerpo a cuerpo tiene una peque√±a ventaja que personaliza m√°s a cada clase. Si tuviera que quejarme sobre este nuevo agregado ser√≠a que agreguen m√°s armas.

En general la actualizaci√≥n ha mejorado al juego en todo aspecto. Y para aquellos que les gusta tener una perspectiva de juego de Primera Persona, tambien lo tiene, para que ningun otro juego de zombies pueda superarlo.

I really enjoyed playing this game, I beat all the missions and had fun with friends. Until one day, some random guy joined my lobby and all of a sudden, my game started acting weird. Now, I cannot use support items, pick up support bags, loot crates and the weapon availability is very limited. I have a weird invisible gun I cannot shoot and none of my skills work with my class. I'm a level 30 medic who cannot use stims. The best part about this error is that it didn't just happen in that lobby, it happens in every game I play and it infects other people in other lobbies that I play with. So, out of respect, I have to stop playing the game so that other people's games don't get ruined.

The mindless zombie slayer I have been craving for a long time. One of the reasons I enjoy this game so much even though it is repetitive is that depending on what camera view you use the game changes a bit. I often switch between first person and third person between matches just to keep things fresh. The devs are active and never gave up which speaks volumes to heart for this game. Classes play different enough, nice variety of weapons. Each weapon feels unique and fun to use. Melee is great. My only complaint is that I would like more blood but that's a non issue really. Anyway if you are looking for a fun game that is easy to turn your brain off and slaughter a staggering amount of zombies and current zombie shooters arent just doing it for you, this may be the answer.

So I really wanted to give this game a thumbs up, but in good faith, there are simply too many performance issues with this game, at least on PC for me.
This game suffers from extreme loading times, especially when quitting a mission, and often has stuttering at certain points in the game, that seems consistent with a memory leak of sorts, instead of my hardware as other parts of the game that are more demanding, seem to run ok.
I have lost count of the Crash to Desktop experiences I've had, especially this last 3 weeks. It honestly feels like a bad console port.
If you do not have friends, do not buy it!

Pros: Supports - Windows 7 - ultra wide screen 5120x1440 - 5.1 Surrouns Sound - real good graphics - Optimized well for frames per second - nice maps & locations.
Cons: Console port controls. Clunky camera & controls. Only one aim speed adjust so you tend with fast regular look & slow aim lock or fast aim look slow regular look. Single player cant be played on difficult settings. A.I. is horrible. Cant unlock good weapons mods unless played on difficult settings so your stuck with crap weapons unless you have 4 human players. Linear maps which block exploring or alternate routes. Game crashed several times then I had a freeze on the loading screen & restarts don't fix it so I uninstalled the game. No one is playing this game anyway. Just check steamcharts.com

Something is fucky in the game to such a degree that, with the default unrestricted framerate, it will cap out your CPU, and in my case do it so hard it causes repeatable crashes. The solution is to lock the framerate to 60, but I cannot comprehend how this is a problem almost 3 years down the road.

Very first launch, and after spending about double whatever listed time I have on Steam, I have had the game not just constantly crash, but crash so hard my computer passed Bluescreen and went straight to rebooting. The only thing that even marginally helped was reverting both my CPU and GPU(an R9-5950X and EVGA 3090 FTW3 Ultra) to stock specs across the board, letting me actually get into the main menu but still resulting in the same exact crash while browsing character bios.

This is to date the most unstable game I have ever run and I'm refunding it immediately.

Short version: Enjoyable experience until the faulty hitbox logic ruins all your good runs.

Good graphics, intense gameplay, extremely quiet community. You might see someone say something 1 out of 10 games. Good for a casual experience but if you want to play on the more difficult settings or get far in the 'horde mode' you simply cannot risk being physically around the zombies due to faulty hitboxes.

What I mean by faulty hitboxes is, you will see a zombie standing with its arms at its side and think it is just out of reach, then you start receiving damage without any visual animation. I've had zombies walking by me without stopping, staring in another direction, and died from four hits at once. 

My best run on the Horde mode ended because one person died standing on a ledge too close to the zombies and then when I went to save them using a special ability, the special ability animation completed then I was pinned by zombies while still in the middle of the special ability animation. I have 0 ping issues with the server and I am confident this is just how the game is coded. 

Compare this to Killing Floor. In Killing Floor, I always know exactly how I screwed up, where the attack came from, how far I was from being safe from the hit, etc. All of this ensures that you can get in the middle of the action and, if you are skilled enough, kick some ass. In World War Z this just isn't feasible.

Only recommended for casual/group play on 50% sale or more, otherwise don't waste the money.

Short review:

World War Z iz a zombie shooter game with FPS logic. There are similarities between the game and the movie. It mainly focuses on cooperation and multiplayer. It has serious amount of challenge if you want. The weapons are diverse and strategy is mandatory. I think it is better than Left 4 Dead 1 and 2 but this comparison is not valid, since this game has horde mode. Overall, could be real fun with friends who know how to play this good.

Long review:

Ok first of all we should not be comparing this game with Left 4 Dead. That game is also awesome and rich. World war z is mostly about strategy. This game has 2 modes, 1 is just story progression and 1 is for multiplayer. There is also a horde mode to kill swarm of zombies in a strategic way.

Story is kind of boring but you can play it offline and easily finish all of it with bots on your side. All of the story requires 4 players and it can be multiplayer or singleplayer with bots. If you go into multiplayer and expect other people to jump in, be aware, the game changes its progression and map a little. It expects you would get human help and increases the difficulty. If you stick to offline mode, the game will help you a little, since the bots are way too stupid :D

You will meet new characters in the campaign mode. Each has some unique characteristics on the outside. They also have customized outfits but you have to unlock them with challenges. This is not cool. Each campaign mission has some sort of story but mostly, it is point to point zombie survival game.

The traps are improtant in this game. There are auto turrets, electric traps, proximity greanades. You will use these to stop and efficiently kill zombies of like 100 in numbers. There are also good number of different weapons from the get go in the game. But in the story, you will start with small ones and discover bigger weapons throughout. Also in horde mode, you will have to unlock them with points.

BTW, horde mode. This is where the game excels. It is basically area defense war. Zombies swarm in and you have weapons, traps and friends to stop them. There are destructable environmental ebjects like fences to slow them down but you will need to replace them when they are broken. The game will throw waves at you and you will be rewarded with points. You will use them to buy traps, guns, ammo, medkit and etc. Bots will not get points, so you have to work for them too :D

In this game, bots are idiots. They don't know how to use a stationary machine gun or take a medkit to heal themselves. You will need to take care of them. That is why this game really need friends to be played with.

I have never actually played multiplayer mode. There are like capture the flag modes or something. I think horde mode is good enough.

There are lots of weapons and their upgrades. You will have unlock points to unlock weapon upgrades, as you play horde mode or story mode. Every character can use every gun in the game.

There are classes to chose. Every character can chose every class. These classes are like Medic, Gunslinger, Explorer, Slasher ...etc. They have unique abilities and they will be upgraded too, as long as you play in tha class. Again you will spend unlocking points like in guns. These should have been separated i guess. But the same points will be used for guns and classes so be wise.

Visuals are good enough i guess. The gam renders literally a hundred zombies on screen with no problemo in my pc, which is I5 966K and GTX 1660 Super OC. I was able to play at 50-70 ms pings online. Not many people are online though. Nevertheless, you may find some people with some patience :)

Overall, very good game for its price. You might get bored after around 30 hours or so. But this game doesn't promise huge load of content. This game promises zombies and slaughter and strategy. You can also find serious challange here. I would give it 9 out of 10.

If you're a fan of L4D and killing huge swarms of zombies, the game does the job pretty well. However, do keep in mind of the following before buying

- Getting the Deluxe Edition and DLCs gives you nearly all the weapons with maxed out stats, skipping the weapon upgrading grind
- Nearly nobody's playing the campaign online because the Horde mode gives you more rewards, more XP, and its much more easier to coordinate a defense
- Horde mode, the most populated mode of the game, has only one map. Repetition is a major problem in this
- Getting the challenge coins (the blue coins) is extremely slow and its required for getting alternate or special versions of weapons so expect a slow grind.
- The developers updates at an extremely slow pace so don't expect constant updates for patches and content
- PvP is a mess, don't even bother
- Don't even try Extreme difficulty unless you hit an extremely high level and learned every map in the game because people will insta-kick you faster than L4D2 Versus players

Despite all these flaws, the game is still fun, especially with friends and I do recommend at least playing the entire campaign with someone instead of bots. Don't stress yourself over the high difficulties, just play normal horde mode until you get the hang of the game. That's my advice for those wanting to try this out.
Better than Back 4 Blood :)

This is the game that scratched the co-op zombie itch.

While it is true there is something a little different here compared to Left 4 Dead, I believe that Saber Interactive delivered very well here.

The main campaign follows various groups of survivors spread across the world map, each location having 3 or so maps associated with its own plotline. I really enjoyed this, while the characters are not as well developed as say the crew in Left 4 Dead  2, they offer their own personalities and quirks that play out as the levels progress. In contrast the Left 4 Dead characters were present in all of the campaigns and had more time to develop as the game went on.

The core gameplay is very good, at first I was worried about the 3rd person view; but it actually is made very well, since the camera pulls back when you are aiming down sights and it feels like first person anyway (similar to Metal Gear Solid 5). The updated version on Steam gave us an option to play entirely in first person mode, though after trying it once I went back to the original designed viewpoint.

The zombies feel threatening, and there are a bunch of specials in the mix as well. They are made quite different to Left 4 Dead‚Äôs offering, thankfully. The common zombies will blow apart depending on when you shoot them, with a bonus damage when hitting the heads; a crucial part of the higher difficulties. The zombies will sometimes dodge and weave around, making this a difficult task to achieve sometimes; adding to the threat and the immersion of the game.

The maps are varied and very different in how they play out. Additional map variety occurs with some maps having routes that change, and the battle crescendo moments have defence hardpoints designed into them. The catch is that some defences will spawn randomly, and some defence crates will randomly spawn as well: these are 50-cal turrets, auto-turrets, car batteries attached to fences for stunning and frying zombies, barbed wire, and mortar launchers. The crates allow the player to choose where to place the defence, given a valid hardpoint that it matches with.

As for the normal play, there are a very nice mix of weapons similarly divided into 3 tiers just like Left 4 Dead. Instead here we also got a weapon upgrade system, where each weapon is a slot and as you level up that weapon you can buy different versions which have different mods on them and different statistics. This progress was very fun to unlock and gave a gradual curve to managing the difficulty of the 5-point skull system.

On difficulty, going from easy to extreme, the rule changes are consistent and the challenge is very real and insane and extreme; but not impossible. The idea I think is that you get a group of max level (at 30) players with max upgraded weapons and try to complete each map in extreme. This grants you an unlockable which is like a skinned version of the sniper rifle, this model granting bonus stats and special abilities on the weapon.

Other weapons have a variety of unlocks as well, by ‚Äòprestiging‚Äô a class twice; you are granted a unique skin for their related default weapon (offering something different gameplay wise). Each prestige level resets your level to 0 for that class; and as you level it up again you are awarded bonus skills not previously accessible. This system gives some replay value and time to really learn a class. 

Since there are 8 classes in the game, there is a lot to try out and a lot of replayability here. Each class plays quite differently, and I have to say the levelling system and customisation on how you set up each class is very welcomed. 

Other stuff is the PVP mode, no comment from me since I don't bother with these modes to avoid toxicity. The challenge mode allows you to play the maps again to collect a set of 9 documents per map. When collecting these you unlock bonus chances for more loot/map aids when playing the maps. This is useful for beating the extreme difficulty on the standard campaign. Also the challenge mode has a normal and hard difficulty; and a set of random mutators that mix up the gameplay. In some cases the mutators make the hard challenge mode  even more difficult than the extreme campaign difficulty.

A whole bunch of high difficulty modes and challenge modes (with daily and weekly bonus challenges) award you with blue coins. These can be used to unlock character skins and unique weapon skins (which have unique stats).

The online play is pretty good, I haven‚Äôt had any major issues but I wish there were more controls of your lobby and a few more online player features. 

A note on the options and performance, pretty good selection to tweak the engine, and the option to switch from DX11 to Vulkan was very welcomed. The game in my opinion look very beautiful; the engine creates a very vivid world to play in. One of the best features in this game are the zombie hordes, which are something special to witness and never gets old.

So in summary for me the class system, weapon upgrades, defence kits, and a few other additional features give something moreover than what Left 4 Dead 1 and 2 gave us. And I love that. I hope this game gets more updates and more DLC, because it is a very good co-op survival game.

When WWZ movie came out i said that "if there's video game, it's gonna be like Left 4 Dead" and i kinda right. There is no connection to the movie i think and it's closer to the book, it's about war/ survival against zombie not "Find Cure Z" or "Investigating Z" like the movie adaptation.

I have to give this game credit for not trying so hard to be L4D unlike Born4Bad or whatever that game is, WWZ is trying to be the game of own it's own despite having the same concept as L4D. what made me like this game more is that it has serious tone like the first L4D not comedic like L4D2 nor cringe like B4B. it's not a perfect game, the janky & weird animations feels off, still bit buggy, the balancing which unfair but make sense considering it's zombie apocalypse BUT MAAAN the game is GOOD. 

First of all the game sets literally in around  "World" not just America and each region has different characters which means there is 28 characters of 6 different regions, you can unlock first 20 characters background story if you finish which each one, it's CRAZY. It's no Days Gone, but it's a good zombie shooter nonetheless. Horde quality is just a bit different is all. The Zeke movement is a little bit more janky, if you know what I mean by that? I will say it is an excellent system in regards to aim and aim assist. At times you will feel like a headshot god with this aim assist, best I've seen honestly. You will be paired with randoms that don't know their ass from a hole in the ground. They will not understand that they have points in horde mode that they should be using for voltage grids or autoturrets. It will, at times, piss you off. You might want to say, "hey fren! Why you not use your points while I'm currently at 0 points after spending mine on every voltage grid and ammo crate?" But you will learn that this is just the way of some folks, and that it means you have embarked on yet another journey into wave 5 of horde mode that you will not survive, even when you have survived wave 20 with a good team that does understand how to spend points on equipment and defenses. It's hit or miss. It's fun to watch my kids play in cross platform with each other with an invite code. I have an X-box series S and a PC that supports the game, and it is a lot of fun to watch them panic as the zekes pile in and overwhelm their position. I look forward to the years of nightmares and computer game induced PTSD ahead of me. Thanks game devs, good job, I like it a lot.

This is a hell of an interesting one - I would argue they have a better game and model than B4B and maybe even L4D at this point - gun work feels crisp on PC with M&K, there's crossplay, the level design is pretty fun (something about going country to country is actually super enjoyable) and overall the game feels good whether mowing down zombies one by one or in big packs with a ton of adds and deployable's. In sum, it feels like an actual zombie game - like real zombie game. 

Ill give it a positive, I think there are some cons, the matchmaking system you can tell is as unpolished as a dog turd, and generally speaking the weapon upgrade system makes little to no sense. It doesn't necessarily explain how you get cosmetic outfits in the early game, and the story (while we know it from the book and movie) feels like it could have been fleshed out so much more. 

But again, the maps feel good, gunplay feels good, and I may be enjoying this more than B4B which I put plenty of time in an early buyer, and the maximum tier of ultimate, dlc, whatever BS they sold to me - so I recommend this without a shadow of a doubt for anyone looking for co-op, "mow-em-down", zombie slaying gameplay.

A solid, but average game inspired by Left 4 Dead. World War Z: Aftermath modernizes the genre by making it prettier and third person. Some highlights include the variety of maps and animations of the zombie hordes moving through the terrain whether it being jumping off buildings or climbing up. There is some replayability with progression through character classes and weapons.

Unfortunately, some parts are worse than Left 4 Dead like the readability of special infected due to the lack of sound cues and specials spawning too close to the survivors. There are too many characters in the game which lead to undeveloped characters as well as the lack of easy class identification in multiplayer. My biggest regret with World War Z is that it doesn't include workshop content for modded maps which vastly hurts the replayability of this game for me. The Ai is also shockingly bad, recommend playing with other people.

Overall, it is a good horde shooter. Well, better than Back4Blood anyways.

Overall pretty fun mostly. In my opinion more difficult than most zombie shooting games I've played (B4B, L4D2 etc). I can solo other games if my friends aren't online but this one, even on easy is rather punishing. I'm just a filthy casual so it's hard to enjoy unless you have a team. A team that doesn't quit on their first time being downed is a plus as well.

[h2]A Masterclass In PvE Co-Op[/h2]

The game does a fantastic job at providing a larger than life "it's us vs them" experience. First off, if you have a group of friends you can play with I strongly recommend playing it that way. 3 players and 1 A.I. is enough, 4 players is best. The first time you see the hordes your jaw will drop, and the terror of it all, as well as the hype, is great when sharing it with a group of people you know. Just when you thought the devs exaggerated it as far as it can go, they'll make you go "no way...that's craaazy lol" again and again. Standing back to back with your team and seeing that you're outnumbered a gazillion to one is exhilarating.

The game is pretty easy on normal difficulty so we played out the story on hard mode, which is also far from the hardest difficulty. If you're looking for a challenge I assure you, this game can get pretty brutal and frustrating. Between grinding your class for perks/weapons in horde mode and the campaign alone, there's a lot of content here already. I haven't touched any of the multiplayer modes. Only hordes for grinding prestige to get all of my perks and story mode have provided me with 69 hours of gameplay. Pretty decent for $40 if you ask me, even better on sale.

There's not much in the way of bugs other than one or two enemy specific bugs we've encountered only when the game is on hard mode. Outside of that the game runs great. Some of us had high-end rigs, others with low end laptops with iGPUs. Everyone was able to get a stable, high frame rate experience, while making adjustments to the graphic settings of course. I'm glad the devs plan to release a new horde mode soon. Looking forward to that and extending the time I spend with the game. It's a really fun PvE co-op.

Over 120 hours in and still playing through the various campaigns and replaying the Horde mode just to unlock everything. I'll just say it now, this is one of the few games to make shotguns function like actual shotguns. If you like zombies and mayhem than this is the game for you, incredibly satisfying game-play and gun-play. In game currency (coins) to to unlock upgrades for all guns until you get to some of their variants which are purchased through a rarer currency (blue coins) earned through weekly challenges. The blue coins can also be used for unlocking unique cosmetics to each character. There is so much replay value with this game just through trying out the different classes alone, all of which can be prestiged multiple times to unlock even better perks the next time you go through leveling them up. This game is designed for multiplayer and is much more enjoyable when you have others to play with, for the most part since there are some players that will kill you for the heck of it and then leave your game. For the first 2 out of the 5 difficulties available to play through, you can play through all the campaigns solo and only receive some challenge. It is still plenty easy to be overrun and lose on the easier difficulties. This is one of the best horde shooters I've ever played and also one of the most satisfying, definitely recommend.

Well it's basically the same game as on Epic with a few new things. I liked it on Epic but I don't like using Windows the graphic's are horrid, everything is SO SLOW so Epic is out. "Aftermath" has a few new features.

Graphics - On Linux they are GREAT colors, sharpness... on Window well it's Windows. :)
In Linux with BETTER graphics my 2080 TI runs 35 to 37C in Windows with it's horrid colors runs 65 to 68C

Profiles -  One new one "Vanguard" Yeah it sucks lol the rest are the same.
Rank - looks like the max is still only 999 yep that sucks also.

Characters - Yep there are new one's so there are tons of them. And you can do first person which is a huge PLUS, but you still can't choose a character and just use that one all the time. You still can't have two people using the same one. So someone will be stuck using the one's they don't like. You're still stuck with the characters per mission. 

Beaching Charges - There does seem to be more of them but the rooms have a lot less in them almost not worth using until the end.

Horde mode - Is unchanged they really should add a few more horde mode maps. LOL Well more then ONE.

Special infected - Seem really easy on easy and normal and jump way up on hard. And do more damage then the old game. The gas guys are the worst for me I can't run fast enough to escape the damage.

Guns - Same as before very few good guns to find and if you find one no else on the team will. And you only rank them until you buy (with game money) the next level. So if I find it I use it then drop it so someone else can rank it up. There are two new guns I think "Light Machine Gun" primary and "Special Sub Machine Gun" also primary. But like I said on hard or above (where you need it) good luck finding one. And if someone does IT WILL BE THE ONLY ONE. :)

AI Bots - They are still really bad, if two people are playing both bots will always follow one person. They still stand right in front of you when you shoot, stand in front of mounted guns. Then of course you need to move around to shoot or just shoot the bots. I play with bots 50% of the time and they are hard to keep healed and alive! LOL

Edit Rank: (Added 12-30-2021)
Well they didn't upgrade the rank you still max out at 999. So if you play all the profiles you max out about level 5 prestige 4. If you take all the profiles to prestige 5 level 30 you won't know what level you really are.

Still ONLY ONE horde map :( raise the rank, add two or three more horde maps PLEASE. :)

The new daily challenges are great, you earn the BLUE LOL they are harder then the regular matches. But they do mostly old maps. 

If you like zombie games Left-4-dead, liked the original World War Z you will like this one. It seems to have a lot less problems on Steam then it did on Epic. Joining friends is super easy, download speeds and updating speed are SO MUCH BETTER ON STEAM and if you're on Linux ZOOM.

Steam has steam play which runs most Windows games in Linux. And the sad part they look better, run faster, have higher FPS, cooler video card temps... in Linux using wine for windows then they do in windows. (THANKS STEAM) Not to mention download and drive speeds in Linux compared to Windows LOL Windows is a joke.

The game ran OK in Xubuntu 20.04 before the big update. After the big update it runs PERFECT! If you haven't gamed on Linux you should give it a try. You won't believe how much better gaming on Linux is then trying to game on Windows. :)

World War Z, a l4d like game with up to 4 player coop and some pretty interesting maps to play, can be frustrating at times and AI is kinda awful and annoying. I consider this a coop aimed game (multiplayer sucks), extremely fun with friends and the maps are pretty detailed and kinda big. The game is heavily inspired in the book, the zombies feel just like in the movie, especially the hordes can be really fun and challenging, prob the best zombies in any zombie game. The first person addition was an amazing idea but the aiming feels junky and there‚Äôs a lack of maps, objetives are similar (mainly protecting a group of people until something happens) and most of the special zombies are unoriginal. Overall is a great game, decent graphics, good atmosphere, fun coop game and a lot of WWZ vibes, not a perfect game but worth it. Also horde mode is just perfect, really feels like it was made for this game and only this game.

If you were one of the unfortunate people to have bought Back 4 Blood and are now experiencing what the latest update to that game has done, then i highly recommend you come to this game instead. The class system in this game is a lot more polished and functional than it is in B4B, the difficulties actually feel difficult and the levels are a good length with plenty of things to look at (minus new york which is very boring). There are many characters to play on each campaign in this game, lots of weapons to choose from, smoother melee combat (sometimes). Weapons can be customized with points you earn by playing and using them enough, same with classes. 

The only downside for this game is really the players. it's to be expected with any game but this game and B4b seem to suffer from the same problem, Low level/new players playing on higher difficulties. you are only as strong as your weakest link in this game and if you see a player on Playstation then you should immediatly find a new match.
Basically a L4D on steroids.

[h1]Unlike Back 4 Blood, This Game is Not Owned by the CCP[/h1]
The best selling point this game has is the amount of zekes that can spawn on screen at any given time; but they made this even better with an optimization like no other. With all those animations and physics on screen, this game has never stuttered, and only crashed a couple of times, and I have the Epic release as well.

I don't like the addition of rats in this, but they make the game more challenging when you're a former player from the Epic release.

The FPS mode, like most would say, seems like an afterthought - it doesn't have ADS, just a simple "zoom in" with your view.

Make one wrong move in some missions and you'll see 2000 zombies enjoying the nectar that is your flesh. 

For real though, this is a solid game that I've enjoyed every time I've launched it, the only problem is that the bots are seriously $hlt, so if you are playing solo refer to what I just said. Some missions will be a breeze compared to those certain ones (I'm talking about you Tech Support) that will test your skills to the max.

I like the game enough to recommend it : It's good and the shooting is enjoyable, but I   L O A T H   the creative direction of it! 
---------------------------------Why :
Great L4d experience , with a new focus on hordes rather than larger bullet sponges. Experience (RPG)system works great(feels good to me)! I guess its a grind but I enjoy it!  Aftermath brought a few more campaigns, that were decent enough;  You can easily play this all night! 

Maps are pretty good too ‚Äì Linear as they are - there is a reasonable amount of variety and many are interesting even if you have played them several times; with the odd secret here and there.  There are other dynamics, such as planting defenses and finding items that help along the way, as well as items to boost your xp points.

Generic zombie types, but are done well, i.e. how the bull or infecter work - both need prioritising, and well if two hit at a good time and your team sucks, then someone will likely die!

However, the creative aspect of the game is so soulless it hurts the game very badly,  to the point that it makes me question why I play it - apart from the grind!  The story is pretty ^&*% and I don't find anything interesting about the characters at all.  The lines and battle chatter are trash (let alone the accents!!! Haha!).

 The music is there to be turned off.

There are issues (as I saw reviewers mention) with aftermath, and this is not even a through review:
-Look to iron sights is not what it should be , its just a sort of change of FOV, and doesn't look great!
-network problems with matchmaking and game hosting servers = dc from session every so often.

Other issues I found:

-Some noobie players joining sessions, who play so bad, that I cannot describe it any less than trolling (most are console players ‚Äì I'm sorry this is the truth!) 
-These same people sit in lobby before the game starts, walk off for 10 mins sometimes, this is after we just played a map, and they did the same thing last time... 
-Bad optimisation : at times,  I am getting Fps jumps which drops frame rate to <60fps when it should be 120fps(at times).
-monitor focus needs changing most times i start the game up - it seems to lose track of the monitor numbers(multi-monitor set-)ups
-I dare you to turn the battle chatter off(or dialogue).  The game is just guns and the odd zombie grunt.

[h1] Intro [/h1]

I want to start off by saying I wouldn't've known about this game unless Back 4 Blood existed. I played the Back 4 Blood Beta, game was iffy and too overpriced, so this was the next best option. I couldn't be more happy with my purchase, I was looking for a decent zombie shooter and here it was, better than I expected.

As of writing this review, I've beaten every episode and every chapter at least four or five times over, I've maxed two classes, and obtained several level 5 weapons. From what I've gotten out of this game thus far, it's everything I could have hoped for. This game is what happens when you mix Resident Evil: Operation Raccoon City and Borderlands with Warhammer: Vermintide 2. Keep in mind I also own the DLC, which may alter my opinion.

[h1] Review [/h1]

Similar to both games mentioned above, the gameplay is fiercely satisfying, addicting and varied. The immense amount of variety in the weapons is welcome, and the weapon leveling system is superb. Most guns are very satisfying to fire, each having their own playstyle. Heavy weapons are very helpful in a tight pinch, and also very effective against hordes. Not to mention, they're very fun to fire with the immense amount of bodies and particles most of them generate after use. You can toggle between thirdperson and firstperson, both have their merits, though this game is clearly designed with thirdperson in mind, which is in no way a downside.

Melee weapons are fairly limited, though with what is provided, there's a lot of interesting combinations. However, the fact that all melee weapons are automatically available makes a huge amount of the melee roster useless (i.e. the Machete, which has no perks.). Locking more of the melee weapons probably would've been a great idea for a sense of progression.

All weapon drops are randomly placed, and tucked away in crates or out in the open. Weapon tiers range from 1 to 3, excluding heavy weapons. Tiers don't typically matter for secondary weapons, though they are vital for primary weapons. All loot is up to chance, which is why there are perks to start with certain weapons; though these perks are partially useless in the grand scheme of things. Like in Vermintide, this game has unique pickups throughout the level which grant bonus experience and currency at the end of the mission. Defense kits are also a very fun mechanic, which almost partially turns the game into an RTS.

Unlike a good amount of zombie titles, this game has eight different classes to choose from, all independent from the actual characters. All classes offer different playstyle choices, classes such as Dronemaster offer a more pet-orientated playstyle for self-protection, while Medic is pure team support. Vanguard is a tank class, while the Gunslinger makes for an excellent DPS class. There's plenty of strategy that comes with picking the right class and perks for a situation, especially in a team. A lot of the perks help make the game much easier, such as double damage, extra equipment, better gear and less friendly fire. Experience is also very easy to come by, as even if you lose a mission, you still gain class experience, weapon experience, challenge coins if you completed a challenge, and currency; meaning you don't feel terrible for dying at the very end of the level, since you still get pretty much everything you would've gotten anyway if not a little less.

The Zeke (zombies) are lots of fun, they act just as they do in the book and the movie, with minor differences. Zeke still tower over each other, they can surround and incapacitate you if you are left alone, they can infect you in certain circumstances, and you also become a Zeke if you die. Not to mention, like in the book and movie, they are attracted to sound. This level of detail is seldom seen in other zombie games, which is partly why I admire the amount they've put into this. The Special Infected are also quite interesting, some are obvious, others are less so. The infector can be hard to see in certain circumstances, while infected like the Bull, Gasbag or Reeker are very easy to identify. Lurkers are almost too quiet in hordes, but are very obvious when alone or with the "Seek and Destroy" perk, which auto marks specials.

Another part of this game is the NPCs in the world. Unlike Vermintide or L4D2, WWZ:A has in-game full NPCs and scripted actors that help flesh out the world considerably. As a side note, most NPCs can also turn into Zeke, more nuance that I didn't know I needed. It is so satisfying to both keep these NPCs alive, and watch them turn into zombies. These NPCs are as effective as Survivor AI, only they go down a lot quicker.

As for the Survivor AI, they need some serious work. As in most games, the built-in Survivor AIs in this game are as useful as a broken pencil. If you plan on playing this game singleplayer, keep in mind the AI will struggle to save you in most situations. The bots don't pick up heavy weapons, medkits, defense kits, breaching charges or virus samples. Bots also don't mount onto turrets, and they also don't replenish auto turrets. Bots also default to a level 1 gunslinger, and do not have grenades to throw or any perks to speak of. They also don't have good priorities, and will likely shoot at the nearest special infected instead of protecting the objective with a fail condition of 50 seconds (or less in higher difficulties), resulting in one player versus 1,000 Zeke on a gate; not a good combination.

One aspect that's positive about the AI in this game, is that their weapons will slowly upgrade themselves as you progress through the level, meaning they aren't stuck with the base weapons, even if the weapons are level 1. Bots also take up positions during a crescendo event, meaning they have fixed locations they can stand at which benefit towards the overall defense; instead of crowding around you. This is especially helpful if you're breaching a door while the crescendo event is still happening, the bots can fend off a horde well enough. However one downside to this is you're ultimately left alone, and a very easy target for Lurkers or Bulls. One negative aspect to round this off, is that bots [i] walk [/i] to where you are if you're being attacked, and will only sprint if you're a very far distance away. Even then, it'll still be too late for the bot to save you.

In terms of customization, there are [i] no microtransactions as of writing this review. [/i] All cosmetics in this game are unlocked via Challenge Coins, which are obtained by playing Weekly and Daily challenges. There is a surprisingly low amount of cosmetics, but I have a feeling more will be added.

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]

This game has it's flaws, but that doesn't make it a bad game by any means. The levels and scattered loot gives for a unique and replayable experience, especially accounting for class perks and the unpredictability of the director. The zombies are wild and overwhelming in a very good way, making it not only challenging, but adrenaline pumping. Overall, I'd give this game an 8/10, I got my money's worth, and I'll be playing this one for a while I reckon. If you want a great action zombie shooter that isn't 60 to 100 USD, then this is the game for you.

But in all seriousness, the gameplay feels like Left 4 Dead 2 mixed with a class system and customization similar to Killing Floor 2. Unlike the L4D games, replaying levels now has a purpose since World War Z has a progression system for upgrading weapons and class abilities. The game experience is borderline surreal with the amount of zombies which get thrown at you in a defense objective. This is perhaps the only "game based on a movie" which manages to far surpass its source material.

Pros:
- Any weapons you find in game will always be equipped with the upgrades which you unlock/select from the main menu.
- Game is well optimized and smooth despite rendering a literal flood of zombies (like thousands attacking at once) during defense objectives. 
- Class customization for different play styles. Different classes have access to different equipment and roles, but anyone can use anything they find in the area.
- Defense waves allow you to place obstacles, fortifications, and stationary weaponry (turrets/mortars) with devastating effect. This equipment is randomized and scattered throughout the level before you reach a defense area, so you'll have to improvise and think about smart placement based upon whatever you've got.
- Hellraiser. I only have one question for you: Explosions? The answer is always YES.

Cons:
- First person mode doesn't allow you to aim down sights. Most weapon models aren't designed to be aimed in first person unless it's a long ranged weapon, similar to L4D or Counter-Strike.
Gun enthusiasts may question their sanity upon witnessing the upgraded variants of the double barrel shotgun.
- The French.

This game, in my mind, is a better successor to Left 4 Dead than Back 4 Blood.  4 player coop with locations all around the world.  You really feel like your in a Zombie Apocalypse Movie. The dialog is pretty dope too!

The action is tight and fast.  You always feel like your under threat, but the intensity ebbs and flows so you don't numb up from the action.  The game play mechanics are intuitive and smooth.  The only complaint I have is that the menu system is clunky and the leveling system for classes and weapons is not intuitive and requires a steep learning curve at the beginning but it's not hard to figure out with trial and error.  Read the TIPS during the loading screens, they are very useful!!!

Great co-op shooter if you got friends; if not, don't worry - the single-player campaign is still worth it on Average or Easy difficulty as the bots help you out more than hurt you.

The game plays out just like the movie with hordes of Zeds running at you. Levels are well thought out and the gun play is well done - lots to choose from in the latter, too.

Beyond the major world locations (New York, Tokyo, Moscow, etc), there are about three chapters within each to help extend gameplay for dozens of hours - this alongside Quickplay and Horde Mode options. Beyond these you can level your individual classes, of which there are at least eight or so, and each individual weapon type - of which there are plenty from pistols and SMGs to battle rifles and assault.

On sale, you will more than get your money's worth. At full price, you can make it pay for itself if you go one hour for every dollar.

I see a LOT of people claiming this is better than B4B, but I check out what games they play, and never see B4B listed.  So, as someone who put in 100hrs the week of B4B release, I wanted to check out THIS game and see what it was like.  The other reviews for THIS made me excited to kill more zombies.  Since I had actually played B4B, I thought I could give an honest review comparing the two as well seeing as most other reviews just had one sentence saying "this was better than b4b" without any real detail or explanation. This review will be in 2 parts and the first part will be First Impressions, meaning the first hour of game play, general overview with more focus on cosmetic design than detailed game play.  My second impression will focus on more of the technical aspects of the game as I give it another go!

FIRST IMPRESSIONS:

ZEKES/RIDDEN: I was NOT, in fact, blown away by this game as I had been in B4B.  I was actually bored of it by the end of one chapter and with 41 minutes of game play.  The graphics are good, but I found the Zeke's to be boring.  You have way more Zeke's than you do Ridden (Minus a Horde) but there is no definition or detail to the Zekes that make the Ridden fun and unique. I'm a sucker for details but not everyone else is, and I get that so don't come for me!  B4B also has more unique ridden with different characteristics that make them their own powerhouse and super dangerous if you get a horde of specials rocking your way.  I found on my INITIAL play through that WWZ lacks this which again had me bored.

CHARACTERS: You get MORE characters to choose from in WWZ but I did have some difficulties in choosing a character that I liked and wanted to explore when starting a chapter. This can very well be user error, but B4B definitely has an easier way in which to choose what character to play and how to customize it.  WWZ beats them on # of playable characters, however, and I do LOVE a good variety!

POV Toggle: I prefer first person, and it was a pain to figure out how to acquire that view in game. I had a friend help me and cover for me so I could switch over mid chapter to First person view and be able to actually get sh*t done!

MAP: I do love how you are not restricted to one map in regards to you are not limited to one city and it's general area as what you experience in B4B.  I did like this very much and the map I did play on my First Impression was beautifully made.  The run down mall in the frozen hell landscape was perfection.  

WEAPONS: In B4B you can customize weapons with various mods to upgrade it and you have different level of weapons pre modded that impact damage dealt.  In WWZ, you don't have to worry about mods, you grab your guns and you go, go, go.  I love the modded aspect of B4B, but that does tend to slow you down when you are on a map and you are trying to switch out guns AND keep your mods.  So, not having to worry about it during a game is a perk. I did find it strange the way you have to choose and rotate through what weapons you want to use.  I love to run mielee and it was annoying to have to keep hitting F over and over to slash and dash zekes and not be able to keep out my mielee weapon.  Again, this is a first impression review as the game is laid out without tweaking so don't come at me.  I plan to try and tweak and edit my settings to make it an easier handling for weapons with my next shot. 

OBJECTIVES: Based ONLY on first chapter play through, WWZ is you bunker down and protect an area where "mostly" in B4b, you are running and clearing out an entire map WITH predetermined objectives laid out at the beginning of the round (Minus the Bar and Dinner).  More defensive (in WWZ)  than offensive game play (as in B4B) across a map.  

**NOTE: I did not watch any play through of WWZ or B4B prior to playing either game.  This limits me to only what I have done so far but also allows for an unbiased review based on MY preferences/experiences**

What can i say about this game? Well, it is an amazing experience and VERY worth the money you put in.

First of all, despite Back 4 Blood being the "spiritual successor" to Left 4 Dead and such, being made by the original L4D studio, that game is very poorly made and under developed, the new additions are cool but not as fulfilling, while World War Z did. WWZ feels like L4D on steroids, and that is in the literal sense.

Small encounters around the map feels exactly like when I played L4D, albeit not as a horror vibe as L4D. You have Lurkers which are essentially weaker Hunters scattered around, you have the Bull which is a more bullshit version of the Charger, you have stuff like Gasbag, Infector (which is a much more dangerous Spitter since it can instakill you in certain situation) and more. The special infected in the game is not that varied and not that "special", but I appreciated the effort. They posed actual challenges in certain maps and not so in the others, but still, a fun novelty. Except for some special infected that are actually different from L4D like the screamer, sneaky beaky bastards who call in hordes of infected and stand in obscure sights, or the Rats who is stupidly strong to the point of multiple frag grenades must be used to kill just one, these are just really really imbalanced (good thing they fixed it the last patch). Normal infecteds are cool too, you can also see the individual detailed differences between each infected of each region in the world (like normal infected in Tokyo looked more like Japanese than the infected in like Moscow for example) and such. Overall the "normal" gameplay is very good.

Then we get to the meat and potatoes of the game: the horde mode. every checkpoint there will be a huge swarm spawn in waves to drown the survivors and the millitary, and oh boy, this is the one thing that sold many people on the game, and frankly me too. The Hordes are terrifying, overwhelming and really satisfying to take down. Although 90% of them are normal infected, that doesn't mean they are weak if you have large firearms or setup a ton of autoturrets and machineguns - make no mistake, they ARE STRONG and will defeat you in a flash if you are not careful enough and work with your team. The designs of the horde spawn and the mechanism surrounds them - the sheer amount of zombies, the defensive kits you have to setup around the chokepoint of the swarm, not to mention, each and every chokepoint is essentially made to be like a warzone, and military dudes despite very useless in helping you defend stuff (most of the time they will all be overrun by zombies and be infected themselves) their shoutouts and battle cries really helped set up the mood for the situation, made you feel a lot more like you are actually fighting a World War against Zombies, not just "four immortal infected with guns mow down zombies" like Left 4 Dead or Back 4 Blood.

The perks and class systems in the game are also very well-designed... for the most part. We have ridiculously overpowered classes like the Fixer, the Hellraiser or the Vanguard, and utter useless classes like Slasher. After the buff came with Aftermath the melee combat and thus Slasher builds are a bit better but not enough. while the Vanguard is still too strong and Fixers/Medics are a must in high-level maps. Saber Interactive actually acknowledged a lot of this and constantly fix and rebalance stuff behind the scenes, so that is a plus, but seriously this system needed a lot of revision.

With the recent Daily Challenges/Missions and Weekly Challenges update to the game, this became the real motivation for me to write a review on this game. I was gonna leave a Not Recommended mark on this game until this came out. Daily Challenges and Weekly Challenges presented a truly infinitely replayable experience to the game, that made the game really interesting to play each time and fun to mess around with friends or on your own now. Before, when me and my friends were done with all the maps, we called it quits and move on to other games since we have nothing left to do, the aspect of grinding the perks system was not that appealing to us since without proper challenge, the game is really boring after a while. This changes that - each playthrough now feels different and the amount of challenge tags are vast, with hundreds of possible combination each playthrough. And it refreshes quickly - once a challenge done, another instantly took its place, so you can essentially play it all day without getting bored.

Overall, this game is now a 9/10 for me. The graphics, the setting, the story and the gameplay are all good, and fun to play alone and with friends. Heck, the story of the game even expanded on the shitty Brad Pitt movie lore which is an achievement in and of itself :)

World war z is yet another zombies shooter game, except this one kinda stand out because of their horde zombies.

Pros:
(+) Good map design, some map like Japan area is really well made.
(+) Weapon variety, not the best on market but it's okay.
(+) Horde zombies, hundred of zombies coming is pretty intense moment.

Gray:
(?) First person mode, good addition but it's not well made. right click aim is just zooming in the view. But i guess it's okay for last minute addition to game. And don't make me start talking about how rushed the gun animation in first person mode.

Cons
(-) Weapon progression, higher tier of same weapon add fixed parts to the weapon, instead of allowing us to customize it manually. It's 2021 and that kind of mechanic is quite outdated.
(-) Clunky control on 3rd person mode, some people will defend it, but in my opinion the movement is not snappy at all. You can't ignore this fact once you realized how bad the control is. Making the game not enjoyable.
(-) Zombies sliding when running in a horde.
(-) Not enough progression loop to keep people engaged to game.

Keeping silent to avoid unnecessary hordes is a key skill to learn.

Gunplay is like L4D2 with no ADS even in first person, but not necessary. Good variety of weapons and classes for different flavours of zombie killing. Almost feels like a spiritual successor to l4d2 with more customization and depth. No versus though.

Two big zombie game were out in 2021, Back 4 Blood and World War Z.(Technically WWZ Aftermath is not really a new game, because it's the extension of the original game, however it adds a lot of new stuff.) This game is heavily overlook, while most people have their eyes on B4B because of the huge success of it's predecessor, L4D2. However B4B was well beyond my disappointment(that's another story) and it's too damn expensive, the price doesn't matches it's content(Ok enough of digression). This game has less than half price of B4B and comes with good amount of content that deserves the price. With 8 classes in total in PvE mode, different skills to pick in each class so you can build it to best suit the team. Weapon upgrade system, with special reward after prestige.(Leveling up class) 7 episodes with 3 maps in each individual which provides long enough game play. Setting up defence with random kit you find. Remarkable characters and voice acting. Now let's talk about the flaws. Biggest issue is low player base, and there isn't a lobby list like in L4D2 or Payday 2, so it takes some time to wait until you can find player(s) to join or someone joins you. The equipment is extremely unresponsive, the extreme case is shield, it refuse to work when I desperate need it, and got me into trouble a couple of times. Other equipments is not as ridiculous as this one but have some kind of input delay which can be annoying. Some of the maps are annoying, such as in Kamchatka, when saving the Russian, you will have to withstand the earrape of someone screaming: Dima, Dima, Dima. Another one is the power substation, because who on Earth puts the important switches scatter around in random place? After all it's still a good game and I definitely recommend it, we definitely need more players, and I am hoping that more contents will be adding in the future.

If you were playing on Epic Launcher since the old World War Z, remember to covert your save file to Steam, the old game's save works with the new game. As for how to do it, there're guides out there already.

World War Z: Aftermath is the ultimate co-op zombie shooter based on the blockbuster film, and the next evolution of the original hit World War Z game. Turn the tide of the zombie apocalypse with up to three friends (in cross-play multiplayer for all supported platforms) or play on your own with AI teammates against hordes of ravenous zombies in intense story episodes across new zombie-ravaged locations around the world: Rome, Vatican City and Russia‚Äôs Kamchatka peninsula.

Was looking for something to scratch that L4D itch, and Back 4 Blood wasn't hitting the right notes.  Turns out this game flew under my radar because I don't use epic.  Gave this a whirl because the pricepoint is lower and the hordes looked impressively huge.

Not disappointed in the slightest, this game is a lot of fun and really feels like the undead apocalypse with thousands of Zs on screen at once with gruesome gore details.  Lots of weapons, characters, classes, and neat settings around the globe.  1st and 3rd person options are very welcome.  Weapon sound effects are brutal.

Definitely recommend this as a real L4D successor.

This is the dumbest zombie game I've played in my life.   There are things that randomly can happen at any time that can kill you and no matter what teamwork you have you'll still die.   Take for example the zombies that spit on you that you have to use disinfectant within 5 - 10 seconds or instantly die, if a zombie spits on you, and then another grabs you, it's an instant death since you can't disinfect in time.

See a few mice on the ground, run as fast as you can, mice can take you down faster than any zombie.   Who the heck sits in a room for 2 years and thinks of this nonsense.  

What a waste of $30, I wouldn't pay $.99 for this garbage.

As I do normally, I started off checking the options. When I saw the "User Data and Privacy Collection - ON" I switched that OFF immediately. What did I get in response? If I turn off their ability to collect User Data, I am no longer allowed to play online. So I'm stuck playing the game with their handicapped AI companions. Freaking wonderful. So if you want to be able to play the game as it was intended, you are forced to allow them to collect user data. I'm sorry, but this is absolute BS. I am purchasing a game from you, I'm not getting married to you. Stop demanding I give you my data in order to use the products I purchased. It is to a point that these companies need to allow us to collect their data if they can collect ours. Maybe then they will keep to themselves and we can have a nice and orderly transaction.
If you want to play a game where you are simply shooting simple zombies, this is the game for you. Gain XP to get perks and better weapons... and shoot more zombies!

Feels more like a spiritual successor to L4D than Back 4 Blood in my opinion. Hordes are tense and exhilarating and the difficulty curve feels good. Special infected feel unique and not too hard, unlike B4B where it just throws 4 tall boys at you in one cramped area.

This game is a masterpiece. Unfortunately, there are very little to do after you reached 4th prestige on all your preferred classes, and most of the prestige rewards are a joke not even worth gringing for.

After the revamp, this game is way way better.

1. New melee mechanics
2. First person mode option
3. New episodes

And much more fun in general. I highly recommend it to those who are seeking an alternative zombie shooter game to things like L4D2 or Back4Blood. The lore in this game can be better but the gameplay is really good. You can go on for hours in mindless horde slaying and not to mention the environment is actually really stunning.

Would've been a middle rating if steam allowed it but as it is, I lean towards not recommending.

Too grindy with barely enough content to do. If I bought this game when it came out it'd probably one of the lowest rated for me personally. Good thing it came out after years of being EGS exclusive to steam with 2 expansions (barely qualified to call it, one new campaign and one new class per expansion).

The recent patch introduced new challenges (dailies and weeklies) but even queueing takes too long to do them. Some of the challenges aren't balanced (some are too difficult while others aren't even a challenge) and the queue reflects that. "Premium" coins still aren't that much rewarding considering the slog you have to go through to earn them. Probably a PTW model that got "implemented" as is during dev's interregnum last year (Saber interactive being acquired by THQ Nordic).

The BOT AI is absolutely atrocious. I don't see why they don't invest in this. Even if there is only 1 bot in the team, they can inadvertently cause a wipe because of their poor pathing and bad scripting.

The game is passable but development or expansion is severely lacking for a 2 year old game.
