First off, the game is just the base game with a few more episode so the game is worth it if you havent actually purchased WWZ from the epic store which i did. Apparently you are able to transfer your progression from Epic to Steam by copying and pasting the files from epic to steam which i was unaware before asking for a refund.

Even with the progression transfer, i believe the game is still not worth the 45 Dollar (CAD) price tag. Wish this game had an option to "upgrade" for a cheaper price where all you have to do is locate the .exe file for World War Z and it would allow you to install. Which im sure its impossible how games are today.

The game would be worth getting during a "BIG" steam sale. I will purchase again when they have the game around 75% off.

There's no practice or training before you get thrown to the zombies. You CANNOT choose your own or build your own character right off the bat. Which massively sucks the big one.  it's not clear or intuitive as to how you're supposed to stay silent, you can't utilize stealth well, aiming is for crap. it's not clear if the objective is to sneak past zombies or take out as many as possible. For the history and back story of this book/movie/game you would think they would build some kind of story arch into the game, but NOOOOOOOOO, you just get thrown into the hoard and you're expected to figure it out as you die, over and over again.  I'm seriously unimpressed. If I had known it was going to suck this badly I wouldn't have purchased it.

This is a really enthralling game. So many different story lines, tons of upgradeable weapons and classes, and one need to survive all pulled together into a brutal and invested zombie survival experience.

I've been played like a lot in the Epic Game Store(Which I receive it for free) like 20 hours, at that time I think it is decent, but this game was quite overprice like 20 dollars according to the content in that time, after they announce on steam and wait a little bit more time to be on sale, it is time to have a look at this game 
Story 7/10
You will play the one of the four people who are the skilled survivor in the campaign that set in all over the world, you have to fight a horde of zombies and complete the objective. I've played like a lot of co-op stuff, it is kind of common to me, but at least it has a little bit of campaign to follow up, it's kinda like you watch series that's not beautiful, but it is interesting and keep you comeback to watch some more, in steam it will bundled the main game into the dlcs of new campaign, character, guns that I found it really fair enough.
Activity 7/10
Follow the objective, shoot down a horde, casual, but it is not boring. All you have to do is grab the weapons that will be better as that mission process or you can take the tier III weapons by luck, clear through the horde of the dead, doing mission, receive exp and rewards, then do it all over again. For the person who found this very repetitive, you may get bored so fast, but at least it is fun for the time when you change the class and expect the a little bit of refreshment and new strategies to play.
Gameplay  8/10
This game will bring the half of RPG aspect, your level is not affect the damage to zombies(Or if you unlock some skill that affect on specific type of guns) skill make you survive longer in the harder difficulty, reload gun faster, Gun experience for new attachment to the gun that you use, or especially give you a chance to counter the special type of zombies that can put you down in one shot, with many class you can be, it bring many variation of playstyle. This version will also add more class(Well...only ONE class) and guns, so don't worry about being bored of the content for a while. Additionally, they fix the reloading sound too, after I have to listen the same sound when I reload my pistol and Assault Rifle in the same time.

i don't found the First person mode is effective, you will get grabbed by the special zombies from the corner easily, which is very irritating to play.

Apparently this review received quite a bit of attention so I'll try to make it as objective as possible:
  FOR THOSE WHO HAVE THE FIRST GAME: so far Aftermath only has 2 additional chapters and one different special zombie. Consider waiting for a sale, and you can play those chapters if a party leader has Aftermath.

  Bought it on a sale, practiced offline for a few days and realized that local servers were not a thing. (At the time Australia, Latin America and Southeast Asia had no servers) So I'm stuck on 200-230 ping whenever I go online for multiplayer.
  There's an option to turn Crossplay off and host a game on your local network, meaning you rely on your steam friends to buy it on PC. 
  My 100+ hours are mostly in Offline Mode playing with useless bots, multiplayer won't be a thing for me until there's servers nearby. (Australia got servers in an October update, so it's possible)

This is possibly the best zombie killing coop game I've ever played, and that's saying a lot considering the number of zombie games I own on Steam. The number of zombies this game throws at you is insanely fun, and it doesn't seem to ever get old. 

There's an impressive variety of weapons, from secondary sidearms, to primary rifles, and even special elite weapons (such as RPG rockets and flamethrowers) you can find spread out randomly throughout the levels. You can also spend experience points you earn from playing to upgrade your weapons and purchase special kits to modify them, all changing the weapon performance characteristics in different ways.

The coop campaign progression is refreshing in its stylistic creativity and its diverse range of atmospheres. The campaign, which offers up to 4 player cooperative play, consists of multiple "episodes" in a series leading to the ultimate finale (similar to Left 4 Dead campaigns). However, this game's campaign is significantly longer than those found in the Left 4 Dead games. In World War Z: Aftermath, each individual "episode" is comprised of multiple levels. So depending the difficulty you choose, this campaign could easily offer 30+ hours of intensely action-packed and mostly original game play.  

To add even more replayability to the game, it also offers a variety of character classes, each with their own perks you can unlock as you gain experience. You could be a medic class with bonuses and special health abilities, or even a drone specialist with a flying autoturret that essentially hovers around you and kills zombies.

Each level has at least one major event where you open a gate or initiate an alarm, which triggers a massive horde to attack. When I say "massive," I mean FREAKIN' MASSIVE! Much like the movie this game was inspired by, you will literally see hundreds of zombies piling on each other to climbs walls and barriers to get to you and your team. In some levels, your teammates could literally tally over a thousand zombie kills. Thankfully, these absurdly insane numbers of zombies are well balanced by the simply bad-ass weapons at your disposal.

Honestly guys, I've never seen so many zombies coming at me at one time in any video game. The bloody adrenaline pumping carnage in this game will hook you in no time. I can't believe I'm saying this, but I'm actually having a hard time finding friends to get the game. Friend or not, if you enjoy zombie shooters, this is a no freakin' brainer. 

To be fair, I've only played this for roughly 5 hours so far, and I've only played through the first episode, but I feel confident in giving this game a rare 10 out of 10. I really can't think of a single criticism for this one. Hit me up on Steam if you want a coop partner!
As long as you don't get Dingleberry teammates its a really fun game, literally every weapon is worth using and leveling...how many games can say that...

I honestly think this game is one of, if not THE, best horde shooters out there at the moment. With all the crap flying around about other games in this genre, I feel WWZ: Aftermath has kind of flown under the radar a bit. Solid gameplay, decent enough story for the game that it is, and so much customization with the different classes and weapons. Not to mention a strictly HORDE MODE for you to test yourself with. It deserves more attention and I hope it gets it.

I want to thank Markiplier for making me aware of this game.

Now I get to kill A LOT OF ZOMBIES!

As someone who's always been a big fan of Horde mode games ([i]L4D, Killing Floor, Warhammer: Vermintide, etc[/i]) I had high hopes for [i]Aliens: Fireteam Elite[/i]. This game is everything that I wanted [i]Aliens: Fireteam Elite[/i] to be. It's fast paced with plenty of weapon and class customization. The locations are beautiful and varied. The zombies are overwhelming and relentless. Now that I have this mini introduction out of the way let's take a deeper dive into the game. 

[h1] The Graphics [/h1]

While the graphics aren't exactly mind blowing they're more than decent. The textures, character, and gun models all look good. The zombies have a variety of models and it took me a while to start noticing repeated models. My only real gripe with character models is the special infected. To be quite frank they're kind of lackluster, Unlike Left 4 Dead, which has pretty distinct models for specials, WWZ's specials are hard to pick out in the relentless mass of undead that's almost constantly trying to eat your face. Although that issue is somewhat alleviated by the Gunslinger perk that outlines special infected in red. To give you some idea of how this game performs, I have a 2070 Super in the DX11 API with ultra settings I'm usually getting a wide range of framerates. I can bounce around from 70 to 100ish FPS.. Unfortunately this game does not support DLSS. However, in the Vulkan API with AMD's FidelityFX Super Resolution (Quality Preset) I‚Äôm easily able to get 144+ FPS. I really wasn‚Äôt expecting such a big boost from FidelityFX Super Resolution. If you‚Äôre having FPS issues I highly suggest giving it a shot. Overall, I‚Äôd say that the graphics are good, maybe even great, but not amazing. I almost forgot to mention it but I‚Äôm playing at 1440P for anyone curious)


[h1] The Story [/h1]

This section is going to be much shorter than the previous. Most games of this nature have some threadbare narrative that tenuously connects the missions together. This game is no different. At the start of each campaign mission there is a short cutscene that gives a brief explanation of the current status of whatever area you find yourself in. Upon successful completion of your current mission there will be another short cutscene to wrap up the mission you‚Äôre on. This is fairly standard for a game like WWZ. Basically every horde mode type game I‚Äôve ever played has done something similar. 

[h1] The Gameplay [/h1]

[i]World War Z[/i] can be played in first or third person if you have the [i]Aftermath[/i] edition of the game which since this is a review for [i]Aftermath[/i], I obviously do. While I don‚Äôt agree with the idea of locking a view point behind a paywall, this is a view of the game and not the actual developer. To be frank, I‚Äôve played this game exclusively in first person. The bread and butter of [i]World War Z[/i] is obviously going to be it‚Äôs gunplay. Thus far in my 26 hours of playtime, I feel that the guns feel great to shoot. A large part of this is great sound design. Each gun sounds great when being fired. From the blast of a shotgun to the endless barrage of bullets being fired by a stationary .50 Cal machine gun. Everything sounds fantastic. For the most part, [i]World War Z[/i] feels like any other horde slaying type of game. With a few notable differences. Every so often during a level you‚Äôll run into an area you‚Äôll have to defend against the horde. You‚Äôll find chests with items like automatic turrets, mortars, barbed wire, and electrified panels that you can put on fences or the ground to stun oncoming zombies. This little base building aspect adds an interesting mechanic to the tried and true zombie slaying formula.  [i]World War Z[/i] does offer a solo mode allowing you to play through the campaign solo. However, like every other game in this genre, playing with friends (or even randoms) is almost always better than playing alone.

Furthermore, much like [i]Killing Floor 2[/i] this game has a class system with each class having numerous skill unlocks that can vastly change your experience. For example you can get unlocks that will let you start with a better weapon, more equipment (like grenades, molotov cocktails, drones, etc.), faster reload times, and much more. Each class can be prestiged multiple times with each prestige allowing you access to powerful new skills to unlock. The weapons in this game also have their own levels. Each level of a weapon will allow you to unlock a better version of that weapon. For example if you have a level one assault rifle it will have no attachments. The level 2 version of that assault rifle might have a red dot sight and a muzzle break. The level 3 version might have the red dot sight, a muzzle break, and increased ammo capacity. 

[h1] Optimization [/h1]

The most impressive part about [i]World War Z[/i] is easily the amount of enemies on screen at any given time. During times when the hordes of zombies are swarming at you, there are easily hundreds of hungry undead rushing towards you. Yet, the framerate never dips into unplayable territory. Throw in the numerous explosions causing the undead to ragdoll all over the place and the performance of this game is downright impressive. I‚Äôve had a few server disconnects here and there. Not to mention the occasional long loading time. However, these problems are rare and haven‚Äôt been egregious enough to detract from the overall fun experience that this game provides.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

As someone who has always enjoyed this type of gameplay, I‚Äôm glad that I took the chance and purchased this game when I saw it on the Steam front page a few weeks ago. I‚Äôve already put 26 hours into this game and I can see myself putting hundreds of hours into it. If you‚Äôre looking for a fun horde style shooter to play with a few friends look no further. You‚Äôre in for a blast.

World War Z is a four-player, third-person, co-op shooter where you complete objectives while fending off zombie waves. You can play it with other people or play solo. The game emphasizes strong teamwork; if you try to Rambo your way through a level, like I did the first time I playing you will die. You need to stay close to your teammates and watch each other's back. I played the entire game solo and bots always saved me when I was pinned down by a zombie and helped me out of trouble. AI of the bots is good. Aftermath retains all the features from the base game, while adding new elements that further enhance the terrifying experience. The new, first-person perspective is a great addition. It brings you closer to the action. There are two brand new co-op story missions to shoot through, set in the Vatican City and Russia‚Äôs snowy Kamchatka peninsula. These follow the theme of World War Z‚Äôs epic backdrops that host each separate episode in the interconnected, zeke infested world. Each mission looks distinctly unique and fun to play. Classes are the way in which World War Z offers the player customisation, with numerous skills to unlock as you gain experience. 
Weapons also work in a similar way, with you upgrading them in numerous ways as you use them in the co-op campaign episodes. Also, in Aftermath the melee system has had an overhaul. Vanguard is the brand new class available in this update, as well as daily missions offering unique rewards which you can find out more about in the brand new message of the day pop up box in the game menu. World War Z: Aftermath is the most substantial, and impressive update yet. New content and improvements to how the game performs means World War Z has never been in better shape. The question is Is Aftermath worth it? It is if you are a fan World War Z and are looking for more content. The new class is a decent addition and can add a new tactical choice when facing the hordes, while both the episodes of Rome and Kamchatka add a couple more hours of content and more variety for when you're grinding for levels and upgrades. World War Z: Aftermath improves on the base game in a number of ways. Despite the new content only adding a few short hours of gameplay, there are more reasons than ever for players to keep coming back for more.

Suppressed weapons are your best friends here, as the zekes get alerted by loud sounds. 

Player class & the choice of weapons is good. I'm an assault-rifle fanatic & the game has a good assortment of AR weapons. I especially like the AK103 - suppressed.

What I'm not happy with the game is the restriction of the AMD FSR feature to Vulkan API only. There're certain graphical features that only works with the Vulkan API - and that runs worse than the DX11 API.

Hopefully Saber Interactive will implement a future patch to address these issues.

This is a fun game but all in all there's not that much to do. There is plenty of replayablility but the game just feels rushed. Gunplay/maneuverability is good. My biggest pet peeve is that the game gets stale too quickly, you can play for ~2 hours and feel like you've seen it all. Being a bit of a fan of the grind in games I thought that with the replayability I could easily get a few hundred hours of fun from this game, well the last 30 hours or so have been pretty much a chore and me forcing myself to do one more game and give it another try and my conclusion is this: if you are a solo player, just don't but it, randoms will piss you off and you can not play missions solo, you can play without real people but you will always have teammates in the form of bots, which are either very strong in the campaign or are just dead weight mostly in the horde mode. Think you're gonna like horde mode? You will! But not for a very long time imo, because you will start to realise how bad the average random player is and you will not come past wave 30 whatever you do. That's on easy mode btw. If you have a group of friends to play this with, forget all I said and buy it because it's a great game that gets ruined by randoms and yes it is short but playing it with your friends makes up for it. What a ramble this was hope it helped you decide wether to purchase this or not

Decent game. Mix of objective and defense. Can't recommend if you're coming on solo. Would recommend if you have 3 players.

Issues I've had:
- Mouse sensitivity can't be fine tuned in the game settings.
- Team bots tend to sit in fixed positions on defensive objective. They won't move, even if they're getting clobbered.
- Team bots are slow to assist, especially on defensive objectives. If you're pinned, only 1 bot will move to you while the others sit back.

Campaign quick matches only seem to fill in slots at peak hours. Only tried a few times, but outside of peak hours I would be waiting an hour or 2 just for 1 new teammate. Not very satisfying to beat levels solo in this game. As said previously, the game's pretty fun with 3 players, or at least a buddy to play with.

It's a fine enough horde shooter game I suppose, but ultimately it feels like a tower defense game rather than a horde shooter. That's fine enough, but maps seem pretty short and the gun play feels pretty bad. The audio for guns is weak and unsatisfying even without a silencer. 

It reminds me of OVERKILL's The Walking Dead more than it reminds me of the L4D franchise, and while it's no where close to being as bad as OTWD it's still not a very engaging game. It doesn't help that characters are locked to specific maps, and that gun unlocks are tied to weapons you can't start with or can only start with by buying specific perks that take up a character perk slot.

I've only played cooperative maps though, so perhaps the versus mode is more tolerable but since that isn't why I bought the game I really can't say.

If I could give a middle of the road review, I would, but since it's either a yes or a no I'd have to say no. I'll still play a bit more of this game, but ultimately I doubt I'll be able to tolerate it for more than 100 or so hours.

THIS GAME SAVED MY LIFE.

I am 28

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

A PARTIAL SIGHTED REVIEW

WW Z is a fun rare beast of a Co-op game as unlike Remnant from the Ashes or Fireteam, It's a four man coop.
Set in the world of the movie and with nods to the tongue in cheek Zombie survival guide it's pretty to look at, sadly a bit dark and almost impossible in places to see Mr Jack Shit BUT it gets a pass as its kinda the setting's thing.
Combat is Fun, be you a actual marksman who can work with a semi auto weapon, a fire spraying noob who loves to rock and roll or somewhere in the middle. Hordes are absolutely terrifying (if somewhat comical depending on your first encounter with one), but they do force you to sit up straight and un-cup your balls.
But the biggest sin of the game from a partial sighted players pov is there is no option to upscale the in game chat that while nice to have, can be easy to miss. For me personally (I have a VERY bad left eye) the minimap might as well not bothered to show up as not only is it in my blind spot but its so small, I can't even see it.
The AI on your partners is also woefully bad with them often wandering into your line of fire or standing next to you while the Bull gives your back a wonderful massage on the hard, debris stricken floor,
The Last complaint I have is you can sweep a area, come back for a weapon to use later and some Zeke creeper has spawned out of spite.

Games fun, It filled in that Left 4 Dead 3 gap back when there was barely anyone else touching the genre until recently. To this day it's still fun to blitz through with alot of mechanics under the hood and very varied classes that bring some clear cut strength and weaknesses to a playthrough. 

The game has a nice duality and feels great when you and your team pull off a nice clean defence or when you're the last man standing and bring out your inner HUNK mode to turn the tide.

Despite a content drought during 2020 for obvious reasons the devs clearly listen and update the game in big ways over time. Already you've got about 3 years worth of content here for the price of the game on launch with some extra swaggy stuff on the side if you felt inclined to get it.
Boring and repetitive.

Superb co-op game!

Pluses:

+ With Aftermath, the game is fair in length. It is well worth price tag even if you can't wait for a sale (IMPORTANT: it is apparently NOT worth it IF you already own the base World War Z tho, I read in other reviews, as this one only adds 2 locations to the previous 5, if so wait for a big sale). 

+ Fantastic gameplay and level design. Doesn't really get old.

+ The sheer number of zombies rendered on-screen and the fantastic feeling you get both when mowing them down together with your team, or the panic you get when you're about to be overrun (and your last standing team-mate hopefully heroically saves the day!). Great feel all through.

+ The game has a lot of replay value as well thanks to the various classes, difficulty levels, perks and prestige modes. All this means you can find a play style that suits you, and that players can specialize according to their abilities to form a competent team.

+ Seems well-optimized. Played mostly on very high settings and frame rate on my 6 yo gaming desktop and it feels great. AND when I sometimes play on my 3 yo mid-range gaming laptop, the performance is sufficient as well, and it honestly looks pretty great even on the lower settings on the laptop, plus I get a stable 60+ fps.

+ On a random note, if you enjoy Left 4 Dead, or you liked The Last of Us multiplayer on Playstation and you felt that game lacked a co-op mode, I feel like this game is for you.

+ Works well both with mouse and keyboard AND controller. Whatever suits you. Controller settings are so good you can easily compete with mouse players on the scoreboard after some practice.

Tiny gripes of mine:

- Probably best with friends (as with anything...) although the public matchmaking system is more than sufficient. My only wish with the matchmaking is that you could select several maps and difficulties to search for. As it is currently you need to select either one specific map and difficulty to play on, or there is the quickplay option that matches you to ANY map on your selected difficulty. In this way it is a tiny bit clunky and sometimes you got to wait few minutes for a game if you want to play a particular map on a particular difficulty.

- It is obviously designed to be played in third person (which works great for this game!). Third person gives you a bigger FOV and a better feel for your surroundings. But if you are one of those that only plays FPS, you won't be happy as the first person mode feels a bit like a gimmick since you can only aim down sights with the sniper rifle.  You also have to go to the in-game menu to switch between FP and TP, you can't do it with a button press if you are one of those that enjoys that. It is a bit of a shame that they didn't add a FPS mode with ADS, and made it like a separate game mode. I feel like that would add even more replay value (to be fair tho, you already got a lot!).

- There are some sections where you 'see through' the level design when you get a few hours in, and can use it to your advantage, and in other scenarios you feel a bit hindered by it. I feel like I don't want to  expand on that since it might spoil the experience a tiny bit, find out for yourself! This is not really a big deal tho as the level design is overall fantastic.

Can't recommend enough! I have about 150 hours on Epic and I never get enough of this game. It is a technical marvel, throwing hundreds of zombies at you while running smoothly and looking great. The weapons are great, all feeling different and useful in their own way. Hard to pick a favorite. The new FPS mode makes in even more immersive and slaying zombies have never felt better. Not to mention the different classes and equipment, most are useful in their own way, had a lot of fun levelling them all up.

The only downside of this game is the lack of community made maps and no real endgame. Extreme difficulty is a challenge for anyone, but after reaching max level there is no real continuous progression on levels or weapon improvement. There are quite a few maps, but adding the possibility for players to make maps and sharing them would make this game infinitely replayable!

Copied all my progress from EGS to Steam

[h1]Guide to copy progress[/h1]

- Head to:

[u]C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Saber\WWZ\client\storage\509380f868fd4399a75020e60a2ad79c\[/u]
Folder after storage (in this case [u]509380f868fd4399a75020e60a2ad79c[/u]) is your unique ID folder and will be named differently.

- Copy file named [i]"user_progression.dat"[/i] into folder:

[u]C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\userdata[your user Id]\699130\remote[/u]
This is a default Steam installation folder, it could be different in your case.
User ID is different for each user, normally if there is only one folder so you can‚Äôt miss anything
[u]699130[/u] is WWZ Aftermath id it will be identical on all PCs

- Delete old [i]"user_progression.cfg"[/i] created by Steam.
- Rename [i]"user_progression.dat"[/i] into [i]"user_progression.[b]cfg[/b]"[/i].
- Launch WWZ Aftermath on Steam, if you get a popup about cloud saves conflict select local files option.

Don't forget to make a backup of your
[u]C:\Usersusername\AppData\Local\Saber\WWZ\client\storage\509380f868fd4399a75020e60a2ad79c\[/u]

Here is my honest review.
I owned WWZ on Epic and never really played it. Just didn't like 3rd person and I prefer my games on Steam. Aftermath is a much better game especially now offering 1st person which IMO is how a game like this should be played. I have played coop but I am most surprised with how well the game plays solo. It is a much better solo game than L4D2 IMO. The game includes AI helper bots as a great addition. Some may say they are dumb, I would say you can say that for all helper AI. They basically follow you and shoot. Not many games like this allow solo progression but this game does. The "run and gun" approach didn't work so well for me. I find the game plays better with a somewhat stealth approach with a good weapon and a silencer as the hoards are sometimes activated by loud noises. This makes blowing up a door to get at storage boxes a decision of if it's worth it or not. Many reviews include hate for Epic and/or Steam or the pricing policies and some believe they should have received the Aftermath update for free, not discounted. For me it was well worth the repurchase on Steam.
The game has a Hoard mode with an free XL hoard mode DLC coming later. The current mode is done very well with manageable wave after wave. With each one you have time to set traps which you can buy as you progress.
While the Aftermath version offers first person view, it is a bit underwhelming. There is no ADS or scope view although some rifles have scopes. The right mouse click just causes the First Person view to zoom just a little bit. I sure hope they improve this in the future as sniping zombies is a lot of fun in this game. Also, the game explosions like grenades are very underwhelming. They go off with a dull sound and the damage radios is very small. Very unsatisfying.
Overall, the game is a blast to play and well worth the price of admission.

This one is kind of difficult to review, since I own the original World War Z, and this game is just like a DLC built on the original World War Z. So I'll split it in 2 parts:

For owners of the original game: There's 2 new campaigns with 3 maps each, a couple of new guns and melee weapons, one new class and 8 "new" characters to play. Reason I say "new", is that a lot of them are just original characters in new clothes. I can't really say it's worth it for the asking price. I enjoyed the new maps, but unless you're a hardcore fan, there's really not much new here for what you are paying.

For people who doesn't own the original game: Absolutly worth it. Great coop game with replayability. You have lots of different classes to choose from, many skills to choose from, tons of weapons, great selection of maps and campaigns, differnet game modes, an amazing amount of zombies to kill etc. It basically has everything you need for a great gaming experience, except for servers. If you can live with that, then you will enjoy this game.

Think carefully before you buy this game. When reaching certain level, you have to repeat play same old episodes again. The content for multiplayer is way too boring. Think that I finish this game in 1 week then what? Playing the same shit all over again for a more difficult level. No way!

Y'know when I first heard about there being a World War Z game being in development I will not lie and say I gave an audible groan of disbelief because honestly I thought the 2013 movie of the same name was boring and very forgettable. But surprisingly the exceeded my non-existent expectations. Yes I know this game isn't particularly "new" by any means but goddamn this game is fun. The gun play is slick and brutal which is everything that the movie was not. The movie wasn't really that violent but more a less a disaster movie with zombies. This game puts you right in the thick of it. Ruthlessly gunning down zombies with peak precision could not have felt any more better. Also this game allows you to play in either first or third person and it's so seamless. But I feel like first person perfectly captures the gun-play. However if you are not a fan of horde shooters you probably won't won over with this one. But if you can get down with horde shooters there's definitely fun to be had with some friends.

The most discouraging lag limbo I've ever seen in a game.
You can't interact with anything or heal or even scroll through your weapons. You can shoot but there's no point really - enemies and players are lagging looong behind their real position so you keep getting killed by the unfresh air.

You keep waiting for the game to fix itself to no effect. The level ends and a cutscene's playing. Characters are excited. You are shaken.
Out of three sessions I played with other living people, this server behavior got me two times. Once near the end of a level and another time almost at the beginning. I finished the New York episode. But at what cost.

Depressing. Unplayable. Why did I pay for the deluxe version. Why do I keep playing games. Why are we here.

I had to stop playing WWZ for a moment to write this review. Are you looking for a BETTER L4D game? This is it. Honestly, I knew this game was coming out, I didn't know it was already on Epic. I had lost track of the game and forgot about it because I had seen nothing about it on Steam. All of sudden, boom there it was on Steam and I saw mixed reviews. I was concerned but then I read the reviews and it was mostly complaints about regional servers in certain countries. Nothing negative on the U.S. front, so I purchased the game. I HAVE NOT BEEN DISAPPOINTED! 

Pros:
* Better than LFD, this game had a chance to get most of the bugs fixed and add plenty of content while on Epic to make it EASILY worth the price tag on Steam
* It's just PURE fun, I'm just playing it solo atm (which solo mode is actually pretty damn good) so I can figure out each level before I play with others 
* Several difficulty levels
* Horde Mode is fun, lots of play time in this mode
* Many different unique characters
* LOTS and LOTS of weapons and different attachments as well as few different skins for each gun, guns all feel and sound distinctly different while firing them 
* Each time you play the same level, weapon locations are randomized, hidden items are moved. It adds variety to each play through and thus extends replay-ability 
* Multiple different classes you can level with their own unique abilities and perks that are unlocked with exp points
* Each mission has several different chapters that last anywhere from 20 to 35 minutes depending on the difficulty
* Game is visually appealing
* Zombies are FAST, if you've seen the movie you know how fast, several types of different zombies that have different tactics, you often feel overwhelmed and that's pretty darn exciting 

Cons
* Regional server issues
* The WWZ: Aftermath is pretty much the exact same game as the one on Epic but they advertise like it's a brand new game
* AI allies are pretty stupid sometimes, will just stand in your line of fire or be completely useless as you get pinned down by a zombie (fyi, you can't free yourself in those cases and you can easily die if you aren't helped by an ally)
* In solo, it seems all allies are always the same class if there is way to change that I haven't figured it out
* Match making is AWFUL for the co-op missions at least, even if I select quick match most of the time I'm by myself in a lobby. Maybe that's because people are playing the other modes, which is too bad. The co-op missions are the best part of the game imo. 

Not really much on the negative side that I've found so far, but that could change once I start playing with other players. I'll revise or add to my review if need be as I continue to play. But as of now, this gets a HELL YEAH! it's a thumbs up from me!

Played through the first two campaigns with my friend.  We played the first with the AI controlling the other two characters.  The AI is not very well done and certainly not helpful.  This is the kind of game that just throws you into it without explaining how to actually play.  I found some parts of it confusing, especially the tackles that I couldn't get out of without help.  This created a whole new situation where both players got tackled/attacked by rats at the same time and unable to do anything so the scenario was failed.  I know this is a co-op game but please put in some kind of ability to be slightly self sufficient.  Would also appreciate a new player tutorial for those of us that never played any of the previous games.

This is one of the decent horde shooter with good matchmaking. The added FPS mode is a nice touch. IMO, this is more spiritual successor of L4D than the upcoming B4B. Love the silenced-stealth part, make it seems like you are surviving in a sense especially on higher difficulty. For general players, Hard would be the sweet spot. Higher than that is a challenge.

[h1]However...[/h1]
There are some negative things here and there, but what takes the fun out of the game is the "FAKE" high rankers. Sure, the game itself is quite a grinding game to max out. Some will resort to the specific grinding loops or even cheat for it. These guys are annoying, especially on Insane/Extreme. Instead of being some good teammates or carries xD, they become the reason for failed runs. So please, if you fall into this group, play on "lowered diff. with your MAXED out stuffs" to get knowledges or skills first, before joining higher ones.

Apart from that, I am happy to recommend this game at current price.

+ It's a perfectly serviceable coop zombie game. It plays well and is optimized well. There are flaws and shortcomings but overall it's fun, which is the most important measure of most games IMO

+ / - While there's lots of missions to play through featuring characters from across the globe, there's also lots of overlap in mechanics and mission design. They all have almost the same exact pacing from start to finish

+ / - The ability to level and customize classes adds some variety and replayability, but most of the traits and equipment one unlocks doesn't feel terribly effective, and collectively doesn't make any one class seem all that different from another or crucial in any given circumstance. Some of the unique class equipment is actually so poorly thought out that trying to figure out how to effectively use it can lead to swift death. Some of the class trees seem incoherent as well, with late-stage upgrades/unlocks going against the overall design of the class given previous unlocks - and not in a way that allows for more specialized builds. It's just all over the place

- The AI for team mates is terrible. They won't go for objectives, they rarely use their equipment, they won't heal themselves or others. The game is a really poor experience if one tries to solo it

+ Crossplay seems to be implemented well and the community, while seemingly not large, isn't toxic like with some other games in this genre

By all means, this isn't a bad game. That being said, this is not a phenomenal game either. Overall, it's very middling. It does some things right, some things mediocre, and some things outright bad. However, the game has garnered a healthy following and I can at least understand why. 

So let me start with what it does good:
-The gunplay is fun, it's very satisfying to shoot most weapons and the feedback is pretty good
-the zombie variety, weird thing to list but, it's nice when every zombie isn't a copy of 3 existing models
-special zombie designs, I love L4D2 but one thing that was a nitpick of mine was that the special infected just existed, there was really no way to connect them to the infection and how they got that way, however, in WWZ, the zombie designs themselves tell you their lore, for example, it's very obvious the bomber is an infected demolitions expert or the screamer was a worker with a mic still connected, it's very grounded world design
-the level variety, not gonna praise it too much but it's a nice change of scenery from fighting zombies in NY to Tokyo to Marseille
-the progression feels fluid and like you're actually earning towards better equipment
-classes actually add some variety to gameplay
-replayability, the game is fairly replayable and you don't feel burnt out playing certain missions again, granted it's not l4d2 replayable, it's still decent

and now the Bad:
-the game is soulless, the game has absolutely no soul of it's own, while it does do some things right, it just doesn't try to distinguish itself from anything other zombie horder shooter
-the characters are awful, they aren't fleshed out and having absolutely nothing interesting about them
-the campaign stories are fairly lacking, granted they didn't need a whole lot of narrative to keep things rolling. the writing for some is just outright bad

Like I said, this isn't a bad game but it isn't a great one either. It's fun but it's not groundbreaking and it's certainly no "left 4 dead killer". A lot of people have been attempting to compare this with the upcoming title Back 4 Blood but let me give a bit of impartial advice, dont compare them, they aren't the same and they aren't comparable. I'll probably get both at the end of the day.

Just an excellent alternative to Left 4 Dead. The amount of zombies this game can put on the screen is a fun gimmick that does not get stale, there are a bunch of weapons to level up and the class and prestige system give this game some decent replay value.

Played mainly on console, and glad I don't have to get it through Epic. I kinda feel that getting WWZ Aftermath is a little bit of a steal because it includes all DLC including/before the Aftermath release for only $39.99. And since I keep getting asked if WWZ is any good I figure why not write a review.

 Game-play wise its your most generic swarm shooter and tower defense. Is it fun? Yes. Every review for any game like this will have something saying its just like L4D so play that instead. And since almost every game/show/movie/song these days is just like another those comments go out the window. Classes can be decent in the right hands and with the right build. Weapons are somewhat satisfying with a couple new additions. The idea of upgrade-able weapon tier is just a bit ridiculous in games these days, especially when the currency used to upgrade is also the same currency you need to get perks and prestige whichever class you prefer. A lot of people want weapon customization, either to make a working weapon that suites their taste or to make a ridiculous fashion statement. The former I can agree with, the latter I couldn't care less but don't look to this game for any of that. Enemies can be irritating at times, or even look laughingly ridiculous when fighting. Lurker flies like a wingless demon with sleep paralysis, and thrashes you like a ditched date on prom night. Bull charges you like a linebacker imitating a sumo wrestler. Infectious Spitter is like that annoying ex that makes you want to take a shower cause you feel dirty being near them. Bomber acts like a cod player trying to pull a stunt from battlefield with C4. Screamer is that trash talker that thinks you won't do anything cause he is far away. Gas Bag is just that friend who farts in a full room and thinks he's funny but because he is in a suit he forgets only he can smell it unless you're dumb enough to poke a hole in it. And the newest addition to the horde is the Rat Swarm, like a swarm of Karen's or other mindless groups of people who harass you for being you or for not seeing things the way they want you to. Pro tip: You might want to bring explosives because that's the only way to get rid of the Rats quickly.

 When it comes to server connections for online play it can be spotty at times. There have been a few times where there were disconnects from just trying to setup a co-op lobby, and though I have yet to experience a connection drop mid-game it can still occur. If this is something that you don't mind then props to you. The AI teammates are just as dumb as I remember, but if you are skilled enough they won't slow you down if you play solo. Just don't forget this game is peer to peer so be prepared for high ping if you aren't host.

 Overall for people who want to see if this game is for them just buy it and play it yourself for an hour. You can always refund it below 2 hours of playtime and within 2 weeks if you don't enjoy it. Games are games, and if its fun its worth it. Almost forgot, since the weaponry has increasing levels there are special unique variants of the weaponry that require Challenge Coins. Challenge Coins are earned from farming Challenge missions that will have random modifiers and only refresh either once a week or once a month. Normal gives you only 100, and hard gives you 350. Bear in mind that most of the unique variants cost 1000 challenge coins and you can only farm the mission twice each difficulty. You can earn them from playing missions on Extreme and Insane but the amount is 15 coins for extreme and 10 coins for insane.  So either be ready to go for a long monotonous grind/wait or be ready use some kind of cheat menu... And if you have to cheat just to get a weapon in a game that should have been easy to get then clearly something is wrong with the games design.

I don't recommend this game for anyone who has the first World War Z, it is literally the same game (no, I don't mean its got the same graphics, mechanics, and overall feel). I mean this is actually an exact copy of the first game, but with First Person perspective, and a new chapter or two. So unless you like $40 DLCs, don't buy it. I've never seen more misleading marketing by a company either. Instead of updating the current game to add FPP and a new chapter, they gave it a whole new name, and marketed it as something new, all the while making it look like something it isn't and charging the price of a new game in hopes that you give them their money. Worked on me, hope this helps.

Breath of fresh air! Takes me back to the good ol days of Payday 2 in a weird way. This game plays very similar to Left 4 Dead with a few differences. One of the biggest differences and one that keeps the game fresh is the good sized variety of guns to pick up and level up and a good variety of perks with varying skills to grind for and unlock. Each perk has different starting weapons which is nice, so youre not left scrambling over the good weapons when going about the level with your teammates. 

When things are working well and your team is cooperating, it is an absolute blast, playing now on hard and it can def be a challenge. Seeing the massive swarms hasnt gotten old and is awesome every time it happens. This game isnt reinvinting the wheel, its just a straight up zombie coop shooter with a nice leveling system.

With Vulkan disabled I get pretty spotty FPS when huge crowds of zombies are around, I get anywhere from 60-144 on my i9 9900k 2080ti build at 1440p. However with Vulkan enabled on a mix of ultra and high I get over 144 pretty stably, occasionally I will drop to around 120-130 but it shoots right back up. This performance is while having a stream open and watching a podcast.

Cannot recommend for anyone that owns World War Z already. Aftermath is only a small content update from the original, which essentially makes it a paid update/DLC with a price tag of 40$. Not just a Left4Dead clone, I think World War Z: Aftermath has a lot of things that set it apart from Left4Dead and similar games.

The major one is classes that let you play the way you want and give you a clear role to perform on the team. And within each class there are different skills that you can unlock as you progress in level. Some of the classes are pretty unique as well, such as the Drone Master which gives you a deployable drone that you can customize with your skills.

There are way more objective types. Defending points, stealthing, bypassing traps, and escort missions are just some of the different objectives I've seen. It's not just running and gunning the entire time, sometimes you take a break to restock your supplies and setup defensive for a coming horde. Defensive turrets and traps can be placed which make these very dynamic.

The zombie hordes are massive. Hundreds of zombies on screen at once. You don't want to get caught out in the open when they bust through the defenses.

I originally bought this just to scratch my zombie game itch until Back4Blood came out. But after playing the Back4Blood beta and World War Z for about the same amount of time, I've definitely had more fun with World War Z.

Negative reviews don't actually have anything to do with the gameplay or performance, so don't let them fool you.

Fun combat that involves shooting a lot of zombies in quick succession. The missions are simple and straight forward. You run around and shoot zombies and then hold your position against an army of them while you set up defense, rinse and repeat. There is a little "stealth" involved, but don't expect much, it's mostly not drawing attention to yourself by blowing stuff up or not using silencers. Lots of variety in the maps and the enemies have the usual suspects in variety. 

The challenge is just right (plenty of difficulties to choose with mutators if you want). Playing alone is not harder, the AI is using aimbot and you really need that. 

You can choose a class and progression to learn more skills in that class is pretty quick. Lots of weapons to choose and attachments to unlock for them. 

You can change your appearance but it's very limited. 

The optimization is just right (not great but good enough if you tweak the settings). 

The new first person mode is fun, but the game is clearly intended to be played in thirdperson. 

No mods needed so far to make the game more fun/playable. The game allows you to increase the FOV, customize the HUD, has full controller support etc. Also no unnecessary effects like vignette and filmgrain.

The only complaints I have are the occasional performance problems (nothing major though, just some framedrop) and the fact that you can't pause the game when you play offline.

I just love this game since I bought it back then in the epic launcher (188 hours playtime there) and instantly bought it again on steam, as it got finally released on steam now.

The game in itself is in most aspect a standard zombie coop shooter. Tho at the points that let World War Z stand out of the crowd, it REALLY shines.

This mostly mean its hordes, as those hordes are the main focus of the movie and the books. It's just so amazing seeing over 100+ Zombies charging towards you while all you got is "just" a assault rifle / shotgun / sniper and so on. It's also equally awesome to just shred those hordes with all the possible defensiv devices / equipments / weapons you can have.

Speaking of that, the weapons are pretty much standard guns you see in most of the current shooter games.
Means you got your assault rifles, shotguns, sniper, machine pistols, pistols you get the idea. 

The equipments however are bound to the current class you are on. So each class has its own equipment which defines them. So you either can have e. g. molotovs, claymores, C4, Stim packs (health boost), ZAP-gun and so on. 
Most of the classes are pretty unique in their playstyle and function in a team. Only a few are a bit blurry in what they can do or should be used for.

Before you fight a incoming horde you have a timer to prepare yourself and fortify your current location. For that you can find defence boxes which can include a stationary machine gun, an electric grid, automatic turrents for example. 

Basically, if you like shooting lots of zombies and burn / nuke / zap / bomb / shred zombies with either smart placed traps, lots of bullets or a good ol' 50 cal. you might love this game too. It does have some issues, but basically every game has some problems or issues anywhere but what they did amazingly well is to catch the theme and feeling of the World War Z universe.
HELL YEAH!

World War Z: Aftermath is first of all is an expansion which adds a lot of stuff to the original game, it is like a remastered version of the original game: adds a few maps and cool features. Yet, buying the Aftermath version, you get all content from the original WWZ ( Personally, I did not know that when I bought it :D )

My review is based on my opinion and views on this and the other game I'm going to compare with. 

- Firstly, is it worth the money? Especially with Back 4 Blood coming out soon? 

Yes it is if you have never played this game before and didn't like Back 4 Blood open beta.
Probably, yes if you played it before and liked the original game but wanted more content.
No, if you didn't like WWZ. Don't waste your money and time again

Aftermath adds the FPP mode that adds to the game the feeling of og Left 4 Dead unlike Back 4 Blood that appeared to me as a boring, empty, generic copy-paste version of Left 4 Dead. Soulless, gloomy, dark, and with minimum amnount differences from Left 4 Dead. I was pretty dissapointed when I played the open beta. I know it's from the same developers but I didn't feel Left 4 Dead 3 vibe either.
Anyways, back to WWZ it is brighter and spectacularly amazing game that triggered ''wow'' effect when I saw damn tsunami of zombies rushing to our brains. FPP makes it look like a different game as well. It is not like GTA 5 or RDR2 camera when it is just sticked to the face of the character. No, it is done better here. But I was upset that can't actually aim downsights eve though I had a scope on my gun. 
Two new maps look pretty juicy as well as the characters, weapons, zombies and more. Besides, the new melee weapons; they added an entirely new meele system in Aftermath. They added classes from light to heavy and each melee weapon has its own perks. Now it looks cooler seeing different animations.
All and all we have an entirely new meele weapon overhaul, few new weapon variants, a new Tier 3 gun, and a new class. 

However, there is one thing I dislike about the game and something that has been around there since release is about the bots. If you'replaying solo, you're gonna have a harder time than if you were online. I had to restart a level quite a few times because they constantly died in hordes trying to revive one another. When they all died, I got slammed into the floor by a charger. That is only one of the few cases playing with AI. If you have the option to play online - definitely do it.

Overall, I think WWZ is a pretty good game that gives a lot of fun and tons of different grind out levels and upgrade all of your stuff. I can imagine you could grind out hours and hours in this game. It's more fun fun if you have got some friends  for sure. There is also matchmaking to help you out there as well. I think it's definitely worth the money whether you're paying full price for the full game and have never played it or upgrade the current version as they will continue update it because they're releasing a new special zombie nex month.

Give this game a go, you wont be dissapointed.

Problem with World War Z is that it is a fantastic game with fun mechanics and replayability. 
But it has got to be one of the most dumbest ways to implement online matchmaking. 

The game doesn't has Oceanic servers and worse, not even Peer2Peer, so no matter what you are always going to have the worst time playing with huge delays in kills and interaction. So, if you live in Australia, don't even bother right now. 
Single player wouldn't be a hassle if the friendly ai wasn't so braindead, the rewards are halved and the challenge is thrown way out. 

Which sucks, because the rest of the game is fun. It is a game where you shoot hordes of zombies and upgrade your classes and weapons based on your experience. It is simple, straight forward and it is always fun watching them horde up into one area and knocking that way with a swift rocket launcher blast.
 
But the friendly ai really drags it down and it has no mod support so you can't even mod it at the moment to extend its life like Left 4 Dead.

[b]Don't buy this if you have it on Epic or similar.[/b] Just buy the DLC there instead for way cheaper. Unless you absolutely must play it on Steam for some reason. In that case have at it. 

Just be aware that this is just the same game you've had on Epic for years. It's not a sequel, it's not an expansion, it's the same exact dang game. There's absolutely nothing different about it, other than you have to start all over again from level 0 on all your classes and unlock all your fun weapons and such all over again.

Some positive reviewers are saying it's ignorance on the part of people who feel scammed by this game, that this is just a re-release on a new platform which happens all the time. 

Hogwash! Nonsense! 

The description of the game on Steam is deliberately misleading. It says, "World War Z: Aftermath is the ultimate co-op zombie shooter and [b]the next evolution[/b] of the [b]original[/b] hit World War Z..." 

This makes it sound like a sequel. It is worded to sound like it's a different game. When you say a thing is the [i]evolution[/i] of an [i]original[/i], you're literally saying that that thing has changed over time from the original thing. You're saying the original is still the same, and that this new thing is different. 

Aftermath is no different from regular plain ol' WWZ. They're the same game on different platforms, that is all.

Please take your time to read this review,gigachad took a lot of effort writing this for you.

I am actually new to this game.I have heard about it and also tried to download it from the microsoft store,but at that time i had a shitty laptop and could not run this game,and i refunded it.

Now,after i have got a decent pc,i was actually looking forward for this game releasing on steam,as i would anyday prefer to buy it here rather than in the microsoft store.This is a little background info,now for the real review:

GAMEPLAY:
According to my perception,the guns feel really crisp and even when they shoot,they feel satisfying.It does not feel like you are shooting rubber bullets at zombies.Zombies also react to the bullets.The most satisfying thing is also the hitmarkers. When you perform a headshot,the hitmarker is red,indicating instant death for the zombie in your crosshair. The game reacts well to you shooting a zombie.You also can find different weapons as you progress.

REPLAYABILITY
The game has tons of replayability,because there are a lot of perks you can unlock and also different types of guns.You can also customise your character,which is also cool.Even though there are only 7 episodes,they have different chapters,and even if you finish them,you can increase the difficulty of the game and get more rewards at the end.

SINGLEPLAYER
Although this game does not have a dedicated singleplayer mode,you can still play with the bots.The bots are not entirely stupid,but i would give them a stupidity rating of 4/10.I have heard about some people having problems with ping,but i myself play on my own only,so i have no problems.However if you have friends to play with who can also buy the game along with you,i highly recommend it.you can also go fully solo without bots,which is extra challenging.I play on my own because i am the alpha male and i do not need anyone else's help.

PERFORMANCE
I play this on my gaming laptop with a rtx3050ti , and on ultra , i get very good performance, getting around 90-100 fps.If you have a rtx 20 or 30 series card,u can definitely play this on 1440p or even 4k,Even with large hordes,I have not seen any large fps drops,so a great thank you to the devs for optimising the game so well.

SHOULD YOU BUY IT?
well,it depends on you.I have heard of some people buying this because it is on steam,but i am a new player,so i anyway bought it.If you are new to this game,i definitely recommend it over back 4 blood,and it is also way cheaper.Everything feels good about this game.

hence,gigachad recommends this game,and yes.you should buy it.This is an order.

Fantastic example of a coop shooter that knows its own strengths; killin' zombies.

So, World War Z: Aftermath. A horde-shooter based of a gimmick from a film and adapted it into it's main mechanic. What can be cooler than mowing down a literal wall of flesh hungry rotbags, right? And it has so many different locations, characters, weapons, tactics. It must be a dream come true, isn't it?

But after a few matches I have a few very important things to share. WWZ: Aftermath has a potential to be a great game, but right now it's mediocre at best. As someone with a shitty internet, the whole P2P thing is disastrous if my connection decides to kill itself. But that's a minor complaint and something most players can live with. What I can't forgive is lack of general customization of bots, dull and sometimes stock sounds for weapons and very poor audio work for special infected.

Problem No.1 - Bots are dumb as a sack of bricks.
Sure, they can be useful, but only in killing. The entire map is just babysitting a bunch of level 0 braindead idiots, who can't even navigate correctly. If they are stuck somewhere, they are teleported to you and potentially can fall through a texture. You also can't customize them, give them different classes and other great stuff. They can't even follow simple commands like "pick this up, refill the turret, hold this position". If this is not true, please let me know how to, because the menu is a god-awful mess. If it is, then what are they even good for? They are useless! How did a 12-year-old game managed to make a good AI and this one didn't? Probably because they didn't think that someone would actually play with bots and threw it in just for show, but those bots are still part of the game and it needs to be done good.

Problem No.2 - Weapons sound weak and feel like peashooters.
How a weapon sounds and feels impacts overall enjoyment of combat in a game like this. Guns here sound weak and I swear, I heard one or two stock sounds every now and then. This is bad. Bad on so many levels. Just why does .45 ACP pistol sounds like .22 LR? IT'S WEAK. EVERYTHING HERE SOUNDS WEAK.

Problem No.3 - Special Infected lack sound design.
Left 4 Dead did this one great. Vermintide 2 did this one great. WWZ did it this one poorly.
If your game depends on huge hordes of enemies, then for the love of god, do some proper sound and art design for them. WWZ's infected are near impossible to detect in a big crowd. And don't get me started with "but they made sound design for them, can't you hear it?". No. I can't. In amidst all the chaos, I can't hear them. Again, L4D did a good job, Vermintide 2 did a good job, but here it seems incomplete.

Problem No.4 - This one is pure nitpicking, but REALLY? We can't place AT LEAST turrets where WE want? We can't pack them up and relocate? Why?

Overall, the game is solid in its own right, but it has so many small inconveniences that just pile up and ruin the fun, so I PERSONALLY cannot recommend this to anyone. My time with it was not an enjoyable experience. But I'll hold off a refund and hope for the best - that Saber will improve on it and make this game into another exceptional horde-shooter.

WWZ was honestly a pleasant surprise in 2019. I had no expectation of the game when it released, but it quickly grabbed my attention and sated the hunger that I desired for another PVE zombie experience. The game in general follows a simple formula of clearing objectives to progress through each act, essentially building on what Left 4 Dead established. Objectives can range from the classic crescendo events, defending a point, collecting supplies, completing puzzles and so on. 

It sounds simple enough, but there's a lot of enjoyment to be had in the simplicity. Some of my favorite moments are the ones that emphasize proper cooperation and teamwork. For instance on an act in Marseille, one person is required to be on flashlight duty in a pitch black tunnel. Zombies are crowding in from all angles and its their job to properly light and guide everyone through the tunnel. On another act in Russia, you're required to complete puzzles involving switches and generators while making the proper call outs and killing floods of zombies. 

I find the game to be far more enjoyable when playing on the harder difficulties. This is, again, where proper teamwork is a necessity. One can't just sprint throughout the level and solo their way to each objective because sprinting alerts hordes in the area. Weapons also have to be suppressed. Firing an unsuppressed weapon is a quick way to get everyone overwhelmed. Zombies only take a few hits to down you, so it becomes very tense. Other things, like proper positioning and crouching in front of teammates so they don't shoot you in the back of your head, all come together to make the teamwork aspect of the game shine. 

The one thing that really sets this game apart from other zombie PVEs, however, is the sheer amount of zombies that are thrown your way. At any point during a level you could be dealing with droves of hundreds of zombies occupying the screen. One memorable point that stands out to me is seeing 1000s of zombies flood an overpass on the Tokyo act as you prepare to defend the area; those 1000s will eventually accumulate in the area and rush your position. 

Which brings me to performance. The game is very well optimized and runs great on most setups I've seen. When I played the game on my gtx 1080/ i7 8700k on ultra settings and 1080p, the game easily sat at a consistent 144fps. The game far exceeds that on an RTX 3080 currently. There's virtually no fps drops during swarms and the game overall just runs like a charm. 

Overall, WWZ is a game that surprised me. I didn't expect much of it. I didn't have hype for it. I just went in wanting to play a little zombie PVE game and quench my thirst in the drought of that subgenre. I came out pleasantly surprised and addicted for over a year. The game is well made, it looks nice, it runs nice and delivers, in my opinion, a great, cooperative zombie PVE experience. I would say if anyone is looking for that, I would definitely recommend WWZ.

I originally bought WWZ on Epic and since then the game has come a long way. Lots of new maps, characters and weapons have been added. The devs clearly care about this title and are working to improve it. That being said I would still only give it a 7-8/10. Certain components of the game feel half baked at times and could be so much better. 

1) Horde mode, easily one of the best parts of the game but since its release it still only has one small map. This is something that should've been built upon long ago.

2) First Person mode, fun but feels lackluster. Aim down sight and true first person melee/vaulting/interacting would have gone a long way. Lots of actions bring you out of first person mode which is jarring and with all the interesting optics in the game it would have been nice to ADS. Back 4 blood has a far worse gameplay loop but they nailed it with gunplay and completely overshadowed WWZ:As addition of 'first person'. 

3) Rats, do I even need to say anything about this? they're a terrible enemy type and should be removed completely. 

4) Unique weapons, I like that the game offers skinned/unique weapons but they give them to you right at the start and it removes the need to level a good chunk of weapons. I feel like this sucks a lot of the progression out of the game. Like the 'normal' tier 5 variants you should have to progress to unlock them.  

5) Melee combat, could be better the instant lock on teleport fighting is a bit clunky. Left 4 Dead/Back 4 Blood did this better.

The game itself is honestly pretty good, it's one of the better horde shooters out there. However, there are no regional servers and this really hurts the solo queue experience since you'll always have bad ping if you're trying to play with strangers and you live far from the server centers.

IF you have friends, go ahead and get it.
If you're getting it alone, wait until they give you your regional servers.

Update to review: played a bit more and I'm switching this review from a negative to a positive. I really feel bad for the players with no regional servers since this is honestly a pretty fun game. Also, it seems that matchmaking will try and put you in a team regardless of region. I got paired up with some Americans when I first played and the lag from that soured my experience somewhat. Six hours later, I got matched up with some other Asian players and the lag wasn't as bad.

Get it if you have servers in your region or if you have friends to play with, otherwise avoid.

TL;DR - the game is very good fun and to anyone who hasn't played it before or doesn't own WWZ, this is a good buy. 

To elaborate: a slightly different take on L4D's formula that allows the game to cohabit in the genre rather than feeling like a worse knock-off (looking at you B4B...). Highly enjoyable in coop and the masses of zombies getting mowed down by lots of bullets or explosions is incredibly satisfying. There is a lot of gameplay here for those that want it, weapon and skill trees, horde mode, daily challenges etc. Plenty of missions too and difficulty makes a large difference. 

A caveat to mention: this game IS the older title found on other services like EGS and Gamepass, but with an added 2 mission trees, an FPP mode, updated melee, a new class and some new weapons. In other words, this is functionally a GOTY edition with all the frills (another note - there are a further two DLC that provide weapon skins and a couple of melee weapons that SHOULD have been included in the base price - very cheeky to have them as further DLC). The value proposition on this one will vary depending on how the game was obtained before. I would say for people who own the previous version, the ¬£30 price tag is a bit steep and they should wait for an inevitable sale. Similarly for people who own this on different services and consoles. Personally, I had the chance to play and complete this during a Gamepass trial and knew what I was going into. 

Overall a surprisingly fun game. New content since the original release, fun gameplay and generally a strong recommend for new people or those who never paid full price. To those that own the game already, I would say this is a "sale" game. Also note that progress can be carried over from EGS quite easily, but Gamepass makes it much more of a nuisance. That, and there are potentially oceanic server issues (in that they dont have any). However, just looking at the game - its a big thumbs up for a simple, fun and undemanding experience that can be challenging in a good way.
