Hey, you want to know something good, Saber Interactive? I'm going to teach you about good game design. Maybe that's in your best interest, maybe it's not. Doesn't look like it is though, so enjoy my money. Let's get down to it.

[h1]Let's start with the bad.[/h1]

When you're ripping off Left 4 Dead and its sequel (more specifically its Special Infected), and I can't stress this enough, you forgot to make it actually fair and engaging beyond "I better kill whatever the fuck this thing is as fast as possible or else I'll be majorly inconvenienced by some bullshit or another, maybe even killed." Let's look at some notes, starting with the obvious stolen components that you've failed to make fun, but you just went "Hey remember the Special Infected from Left 4 Dead and Left 4 Dead 2? Let's make them as obnoxious as humanly fucking possible, that's super cool."

You know that Charger ripoff you call the Bull for example? It's actually really not fun to engage him considering he can change his course of direction at an immediate basis and snatch you up no matter how off his initial course you run, which makes the point of dodging his charge completely moot. Hey, even better is when your brokedick A.I. units stand there like gape-mouthed invalids while you get pummeled to death like a pit bull and a defenseless child. Chef's kiss, gotta love that.

And you know what's really awesome is having your Hunter ripoff having little to no unique noise cue in a swarm full of screaming, guttural groan uttering zombies so he can ambush you when you and your useless A.I. bots (oh, there's a lot of a fuckheap there, let me tell you) try to put your back to whatever walls you can so he can eat your health down like a ravenous animal while your useless A.I. bots just stand there uselessly and jerk themselves off into a do-nothing stupor. That's fucking awesome, let me tell you.

The Gasbag is literally just the Smoker with its originally intended (but ultimately removed) damaging smoke put back intact, but with no tongue. That's it. And it's also extremely fucking annoying to have to deal with when he's in your Goddamn way, too. What's better is when he dies in a room where your team is stationed (you know, that team with the really brokedick A.I. I keep bringing up?) and your zombies you keep pouring in, and pouring in, and pouring in, because you people failed at making a director-esque entity that gives the slightest breather (you know, like Left 4 Dead has?) and you're stuck with the Gasbag fucking you up and no viable escape. Fucking awesome, let's just keep that. Hey, make this scrawny chode a bullet sponge for no discernible reason while we're at it.

The Infector. Wow, what a name for a special zombie... amid a bunch of other infectious zombies I guess.
It's literally just the Spitter with the added nonsensical mechanic of "let's make you stand in one spot and take the time to disinfect yourself, because you've got the time to do that when you're surrounded by countless undead in your immediate physical proximity that will not leave you the fuck alone; have fun doing that by the way when your A.I. are fucking terrible." How very innovative.

The Bomber (my God, you just couldn't help yourselves, could you?) is literally the original L4D Boomer, as in the beta version one that just exploded and severely damaged you. That's it. The Screamer is just the exact same as the removed Special Infected with the [b]exact same name[/b] from the Left 4 Dead series. So all in all what we have here are beta elements from a game with better execution that are more player friendly, taken from a game that clearly inspired this one, and are made to be the most obnoxious trash possible. Did I mention the rat swarms with no collective hitbox that can quite literally down your whole team, useless brokedick A.I. or not? Because this seems like the place to do that. Yeah so there are rat swarms that will fuck you up. I'm done complaining now, so let's talk about the positives. Or whatever positives there are.

[h1]Moving along.[/h1]

Let's talk about gameplay for a moment. If you're familiar with Left 4 Dead, it's literally that with a class-based system and action RPG system layered on top and with weapons customization so that actually makes it stand a little more on its own; these things give this game a little bit more going for itself when it's clearly struggling with its own identity and what it tried to copy. Let me state something positive while it's at the forefront of my mind. The addition of a first-person camera was a genius move. I had this game on Epic Games Store (although for free), and playing third-person was just completely obnoxious. Saber Interactive did something good here. The guns are fun to collect (and even more fun to shoot), it's fun to level up your survivor and give them more abilities and to produce a more robust, resilient team against the undead elements. It's completely satisfying to set up perimeter defenses (another thing that helps this game stand apart) and watch zombies just get shredded to bits and electrified pieces as well, not that it matters considering the best of preparation can't really unscrew you from garbage A.I., so I never really tend to bother with them. I end up getting boned no matter what, many times.

By the way, can I ask what the point is of giving us time to set up said perimeter defenses in the form of a countdown clock, while your meth head zombies still won't leave my party alone? I see what you were going for, that whole "calm before the storm" bit Left 4 Dead's director does before starting a major horde scenario, but the problem is that [b]you've forgotten the fucking calm[/b]. All you've accomplished is "the F2 tornado before the F5." It removes any sense of tension building because there are no low points that further accentuate the high points of adrenaline and action. It's just constant, non-stop fucking around.

Oh and the overly-serious voice actors and characters are ridiculous. They're nobody interesting, charming, likable. That's about it for that.
Let's talk about character design from an artistic perspective for a moment because I feel like this is important: When Valve made Left 4 Dead and its sequel (man, I just can't shut up about that game in comparison to this one, small wonder why that is), they designed the characters to be both lively and colorful so that people could relate them to [b]actually being alive[/b], to [b]establish a visual cue that yes, these are your teammates and that it is probably not best to shoot near them, at their general direction or otherwise[/b]. It helped maintain visual beacons in a horde of greying faces and flesh, gnashing teeth and flailing limbs. It's all about the visual cues in your immediate surroundings. I have no idea why the Hell you would pillage so much except this one critical thing.

Oh yeah, as an aside, you also can't defend your teammates once you're incapped.
So you guys stole all this from a better game but left out all the parts that make it team-oriented or even playable. Laughable.

I can't really think of too many positive things to say about this game. Yes, the graphics are great. [b]Whatever[/b].
Is it fun? Yes, when it's not extremely frustrating at specific intervals because of shitty Special Infected design, or when something unexpectedly stupid happens or your A.I. members just ridiculously screw the pooch in a boneheaded way.
If you want to shoot zombies and not be so serious about it, get the game. I'm going to keep playing it in spite of these grievances because they've already got my money because [b]I am not a very intelligent person[/b], and plus it [b]can[/b] be fun. But when it's not fun, it is [b]really[/b] not fun.

Oh, and
[h1]HOW CAN I NOT PAUSE THIS SHIT ALSO REMOVE THE FUCKING RATS, THANKS.
And don't go to the Steam Community Forums on this game unless you want to be met with two very obvious idiot shills, by the way.[/h1]

Very similar to Left 4 Dead but with 100x the zombies, 40 upgradeable weapons, 7 campaigns, 8 classes with upgradeable perks, and the ability to switch between 1st and 3rd-person mode. It's a very fun COOP zombie shooter, and the progression system gives you plenty to work toward as you improve your weapons and classes.

Optimisation and PC features are great. This runs on Unreal Engine 4, so you should have some idea of what to expect. Graphically it looks great, the controls are fluid and responsive, and you get options for field of view, film grain, etc. There's also AMD FSR for lower-spec PC's, though I haven't tried it myself. On a 2080 Super and i7 6700K, I've had no issues at all holding 144fps on the Ultra settings at 1440p. Smooth as silk and feels great to play.

This 'Aftermath' version contains every single piece of content from the 2017 game, including all the weapon DLC's, the Game of the Year content, and the French expansion pack. It also includes 2 new campaigns, several new useful weapons, first-person mode, and a new Horde XL mode with even more zombies.

The general gameplay is very much like L4D; 4 survivors in each campaign have to make their way through environments filled with hundreds of zombies, while completing objectives, flipping switches, fetching items or defending against waves of 1000's more zombies. It's a fun COOP experience, and very challenging on the harder difficulties.

Each playthrough is randomised, with some areas having branching paths, different objectives, different weapons and gear, and different enemy counts. Sometimes you'll find areas filled with claymores, other times it will be hostile turrets, etc. It's fun not knowing how the mission will play out each time.

During wave defence sections, you can pick up defensive items like Auto Turrets, Manual Turrets, Electric Fences and more, and place them in areas to help fend off the hordes. These are also randomized each time, so you might get unlucky and have very few useful defenses sometimes.

There's somewhat of a stealth system too, so you need to prioritise suppressed weapons (and upgrading existing weapons with suppressors) so that you don't bring a horde of 200 zombies every time you fire your guns.

There are special infected much like L4D; you've got the Bull (charger), Infector (spitter), Creeper (jockey), Bomber (boomer), Rat Swarms, and in October the 'Booster'. If any of these catch a lone player off-guard, it could mean their death.

If you're a fan of L4D, I highly recommend checking this out!

Been playing since it was still an Epic exclusive. Been waiting for the Steam release (I trust this platform more.). This and L4D are my favorite zombie co-op shooters. The guns audio and visual feedback against the zombies are satisfying. I never get tired of repeating campaigns due to varying difficulties. Will always have your adrenaline rushing.

TLDR: One of my favorite games now on Steam in a convenient package that also includes the latest DLC! By far my favorite zombie game and In my opinion, way more fun than B4B. Highly recommended!

The negative reviews are definitely caused by misconceptions that some people had and are not fully deserved. 

The sentence "the next evolution of the original hit WWZ" might indeed be misleading I guess. To be absolutely clear - World War Z: Aftermath is a DLC for the original game. The difference is that it is now free from being an Epic exclusive and it came to steam as a completely new package. Would you rather see the base game for 20-30 E and the expansion for 20 E on the Steam store? It's just conveniently packed up at a good price. On top of that, there are several free updates coming soon!

People complaining that it is a full price game? The expansion is pretty great and has tons of new content, on it's own it's still 20E on Epic to do the upgrade. Basically, if you're getting it on Steam, for the extra 10E you're actually getting the full GOTY edition of the base game (which was worth 40E) + the expansion on top of it. 

About matchmaking. Can't be sure how it actually is in places like Australia but in Europe the game has been very much alive. Even over the past month I had no issues finding a full party for insane and extreme runs, right now it seems even better with full super easy crossplay capabilities. Lobbies match you automatically with PS, XBOX and Epic and if you just want to play with your buddies from a different platform it's as easy as sharing a code. I'm really struggling to find another game where it's so easy to play in a cross platform party. We even managed to find people to play PvP which has been completely dead for quite some time.

In comparison, I tried B4B in the beta and it just felt so stiff... The zombies are just meh and feel really pale in comparison to the swarming hordes in WWZ. The gunplay in B4B felt off as well. I loved L4D back in the days so maybe that's why the addition of the ADS and guns taking half of my screen feels odd. Whenever I shot the zombies in B4B I felt there's fake blood spraying all over the place and that was it. Don't even get me started on how disappointing a pipe bomb explosion was but maybe there was just something wrong with the ragdolls. It just feels so damn good when the horde is rushing and there are body parts and zombie bodies flying all over the place. You can shoot half a zombie's head off or just it's hand.. it looks and feels great and the weapons feel just right. The progression system in feels a lot better too in WWZ. At it's current state, in my opinion WWZ is vastly superior and just simply more fun.

About the launcher... EGS is just inconvenient so I was looking forward to the steam release where the social overlay is not utter garbage. I also like to have all my things in one place. I was willing to start the progression from scratch but as a cherry on top the savegames are very easy to transfer from Epic. Hell.. I even just dumped all the EGS WWZ files into my steam folder and could play straight away saving me time on the 30GB download.

To sum it all up. WWZ is just a game that I love coming back to and I'm super chuffed to see more content for it. For some reason, hitting a dozen zombies in the head one after another and/or playing a medic and helping out the team just makes me happy :D

Yes.

When the game description mentioned that you can only play as certain characters per area in the co-op campaign, but could play as any in multiplayer, I thought that meant in the story mode you have to play as certain characters but in the regular replayable multiplayer missions you get to play whoever you want. Apparently their definition of "multiplayer" is the competitive game mode. The phrase "co-op campaign" here refers to the entire rest of the game.

So you don't get to make your own character, massively destroying player customization and individuality, but you also only get to play as specific characters in each sub section of missions; thus you can't even ground yourself in puppeteering a specific premade character you have to switch to a completely new individual every single sub section. In a game that was originally designed to be in third person, which puts huge emphasis on the appearance of the player.

There are layers to the baffling amount of incompetence at play here.

Besides destroying customization, forcing players into premade characters does save on short term development but it also hampers the creators long term. Because now that they've created all these completely different characters with completely different body types, designing cosmetics to fit all of them is much more difficult. Which results in developers adding dozens of cosmetics into the game, but each character only has access to the few that were made explicitly for them and all the cosmetics made for characters each player doesn't like are now going to waste. Which is blatantly observable in this game too, each character only has a couple of lazily designed alternate cosmetics because the developers shortsightedly did not design them to be compatible with modular cosmetics like an actual customization system would be.

But what's truly disturbing is that the developers added so many premade characters into this game that there's now enough faces and body types for them to have made an actual basic customization system out of it. But they didn't, not only did they go out of their way to design all these completely different character models instead of consolidating it all as one customization system but they explicitly prohibit you from playing as most of them in every single mission. So they put the same amount of effort into producing a more restrictive system, then added a completely new form of restriction onto it which devalues the breadth of their own work.

What, do you think the lore of this stock copy paste zombie world is so deep and precious that you had to restrict the characters per chapter to preserve the integrity of the story? What's the story? Random humans run around a random environment inexplicably fighting off an impossible amount of scientifically illogical enemies while performing asinine objectives that could of been completed by whoever took the time to set them up before the protagonists got here; meanwhile the protagonists are casually finding weapons of mass destruction littered around the scenery and can survive blatantly devastating wounds with little duress then completely mend those wounds by just opening up a medical kit on the fly likely without any extensive training in actual medical science. I scarcely believe from a story standpoint something so bereft of creativity would be engaging the first time around let alone after players have been through these missions potentially dozens of times, since this is supposed to be replayable.

But I think it's more likely that the game is just this way simply because the developers made a very foolish design decision which quite obviously only made things worse for zero ultimate benefit.


Absolutely saddening that I was so looking forward to finally playing another third person multiplayer shooter only to find out it has possibly the most restrictive and completely irrational character system I've ever seen in the game. Which is not only a fundamental design problem in general but is exceptionally worse in a game where you're constantly looking at the character you're meant to be controlling. What an entirely unnecessary stroke of absolute folly.

If you're interested in finding some games that I do positively recommend they can be found on my curator page [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38950844-Anoemalous/] here [/url].

I would wait for longer before posting a review normally but I've seen some of the usual "<1h reviews" going like "not fun, bad game" so I'll give it my 2 cents here:

The only lore I know from WWZ is from the Southpark parody, watched the movie like years ago but thats not rly anything necessary to enjoy the game, it comes down to "lotta zombies, gotta get outta there" plot-line. 

For <34‚Ç¨ you can play on (currently) 7 or so different "episodes" (Regions) in campaign. 
Each region has multiple levels. 
So far I have finished the first episode taking place in New York. 
The levels seem to have some kind of RNG to it making it better for replayability (mission items & loot can spawn in different locations). 

The amount of weapons is quite a bunch. From pistols, to rifles to an explosive crossbow
Lots of weapons can be upgraded by using them and "leveling them". 

There also are a bunch of classes to level (takes a while) and plenty of perks to unlock. 

Core gameplay loop is alright. 
If you like L4D you will most likely like this game aswell. 

Using airstrikes, mortars, heavy mgs and other stuff to slay zombies is fun though and if you don't expect the world you can def. get your moneys worth. 
For me this is a decent AAA title for an Indie-game-pricetag. 


Negatives would be:
-Climbing can be a bit clumsy 
-There is no real AimingDownSight / using scopes (yet? I hope that will become a thing in later updates). 
-You can only play when you accept their EULA (which is stated here in the storepage) which is ok but then there is another EULA which is necessary for online play which isnt listed here in the Steam store page. 
An oversight imho.
-It has gone the "epic games exclusive" route, something that imho only belongs to console people, but not to the PC pride.

Overall score:
4/6 bananas
